Damn I don't even know where to start. Excellent performances, direction, the cinematography. The cinematography!!!!!!!!!!! It looks like the film was shot in one single take. Plus the whole soundtrack was just drum solos but it still one of the best and most unique soundtrack I have ever heard.

Had a slow start. To me, this movie was geared towards drama folks. The storyline honestly did not catch my interest because I have no relation or interest in Broadway. The movie did finally pick up and raised a lot of questions.  It got you thinking especially the ending. I did not like the weird action scenes out of nowhere- again got you wondering what the heck is this? But, I feel this movie was so highly raved because  of the movie style of the constant filming with no cuts. It was odd at first, but pretty cool.  Overall, if you're not an avid theater goer, broadway actor, or in the  drama club - I don't feel this appeals to the regular folks.

Beware, this review contains spoilers. 
This is a great movie, with no doubt. Technically, it is astounding. And it is emotionally strong. Very strong. It really raises strong feelings and emotions. 
Unfortunately for me, I got not pleasant emotions. When I left the theatre I had a very unpleasant feeling of distress, as if somenthing really bad and unpleasant was to happen any time. 
Some friend told me that, on the flying scene, she had a  beautiful impression, like in a dream of flying. But for the unfortunate one that never had such a dream in his life, this part was completely misunderstood, it was just the delirium of a poor one. 
In the end, after Rigan jumps out the window of his hospital room, somebody feels he was, at last, able to fly. I am rather on the side of who believes he died, smashed on the ground under the window, his doughter smiles because he is, at last, free from his obsessions, at the cost of his life.
Well, that feeling of the first group makes of Birdman a great movie. With my kind of feeling, Birdman is beautiful, but unpleasant: something to try to forget as soon as possible. 
I have seen it twice. Now I will try to forget it. ASAP.
predobro reziran! dugo traje...

acting and cinematography was good. but storyline (if even existent) was slow and dull. the super hero parts were annoying and even painful to sit through. too long. overall terrible. could not recommend it to anyone.
Interesting cinematography and fine acting (particularly by Ed Norton), but a cliched and predictable screenplay and plot.   Most characters were one-dimensional, filled with self-absorbed angst.

Just so perfect in so many ways but finally feels like an artsy navel-gazing pretentious lament.  Yes, 'Birdman' I will watch you again, but I will not like myself any better for the experience.  Why does something so good have to be so... meh?
What a waste of two hours. Only pretentious Hollywood would consider this a film let alone be up for an Oscar. Sad commentary on the Academy!!

Birdman succeeds as Michael Keaton's comeback movie (sorta) with a layered narrative comprised of emotion, humor and thought-provoking philosophy and a technical aspect that gives other cinematographers a run for their money. The entire cast also give excellent performances in this wonderful film. Director Alejandro Gonzalez Innaritu's Birdman is a triumphant black comedy that gets serious at times  and is exceptionally well done. One of the best films modern cinema has to offer.
Puro salita at pag-uusap ang pelikulang to kaya hindi natin to dapat tangkilikin.

Interesting movie for sure though not the type I'm usually interested in watching. I just happened to be able to watch a free movie on a flight to San Francisco from Florida and chose it. 

I can see why it's gotten such high ratings and reviews. I thought Michael Keaton was awesome along with Edward Norton. The rest of the cast was great too and it was interesting seeing their different interactions. 

The story itself was super interesting and I of course loved all of the superhero related aspects. This of course being due to my love of superheroes. The idea of this famous actor for playing a superhero role to try and move on to become something more is fun. 

Overall, again, not really my type of film I actively seek out but I enjoyed it nonetheless.

92%
Watched this on 07/02/15
In my opinion, Birdman must win all the Oscars in the acting category, including Emma Stone for best supporting actress, but most probably those losers will give it to Patricia Arquette. Michael Keaton gives an Oscar worthy bravura performance and so does Edward Norton. The visual effects of the film are disappointingly unoriginal. The layered story gives enough impetus to all characters. The film is a reflection over the money driven Hollywood that makes stupid superhero films just for making money. Incidentally, the film shares my views on critics.

The performances in Birdman are wonderful. The story a bit confusing. This is a story of an actor who is literally losing his identity. He is not sure what is real and what is not real based on the fact that the truth is buried deep within a chaotic whirlwind of perceptions. And this is exactly how the movie plays. You are never quite sure as to really where things stand for our anti-hero except he is psychologically on a sinking ship. We know this from the very beginning. The screenplay keeps the audience off balance as we try to unravel the puzzle as the camera weaves through a maze of illusion and reality. It is perfect that this plays out in an actual theatre, because illusion exists on stage and also within the psyches that quite can't see beyond oblivion. Michael Keaton plays the actor beautifully and we see a truth in his disintegration. Is he his past career which has disappeared or is there an ability to make sense of  his being. Ably supported by Naomi Watts as a fellow actress, Ed Norton an upstart, New York actor who is full of himself, and Emma Stone as the actor's daughter that can't quite see beyond the veil of her twelve step program. Hollywood is playfully skewered. This is the twenty first century All About Eve, but for a man. Existential cinematography that has long shots makes the dream seamless. To say that this is perfection, would be an overstatement. It pokes fun at the masses, the press, and our trivial way to delude ourselves. Yet it is fascinating nonetheless.

Heard so much hype about this movie on the web that I had to see it, full-knowing that it's not my bag. Yes, it's a weird one, an unflattering satire on Hollywood's obsession with fame, greed and artistic merit. While I can take or leave the story's twists, the acting of Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, Zach Galifinakis, Naomi Watts and Emma Stone is top-notch and the clever "no-cut-away" camera editing made this a memorable movie experience, especially since I watched it outdoors in the rain!

Pretentious and  shallow vomiting of not-so new, not-so clever criticism on a wide (WIDE) variety of subjects.
Was the "bird"  meant to sound just like Mr. Doggie from Little Brittain in America?  I couldn't figured it out.
Anyway, Mr. Doggie was more convincing, smart and well, just funnier. 
Lubezki does , as always, an excellent job and Keaton's performance is quite enjoyable, that's why I gave it 2 and a half stars instead of 2 (1 3/4)
A very odd yet fascinating film. I just loved it!
love the cinematography!
Interesting performance from all the actors, they are totally feeling the movie, they "make art". Still, the story it's a little bit off in some parts, but bottom line, it's a great movie.
Ed Norton stunning as usual & an unexpectedly brilliant performance from Keaton!

I was skeptical at first, worse I didn't like the movie. The minimalist jazz music, the camera following around the actors in a tiny theater, those actors acting (more like over-reacting) hysterical... all that hustle gave me a headache. Fortunately there was Emma Stone's character to which I kind of identified because my father is an ageing artist (like Keaton's character) still obsessed with his ego and image. It was her character who said the most interesting lines. Her rant at her father sums up the idea of the movie pretty well. And the ending is beautiful. The movie is quite original and definitely has talent inside. I just didn't like it more than that. I guess I must be tired of Hollywood (or Broadway) gazing at its navel.

Sorry Michael Keaton but you failed to deliver on Birdman. Here's hoping Alejandro González Iñárritu's next movie has some scribbling of a takeaway. I left the hall feeling numb, shaken up and let down. After all that hype, I found myself asking 'What did I just sit through?' While I appreciate the effort taken to build up each scene, not enough of the film was spent dissecting and evolving Riggan Thompson's alter ego. While Emma Stone might've thought her role was meant to be portrayed as minimalist she could've added a lot more meat to her character. The director blew a very clear cut opportunity to take the human form aka Riggan Thompson and transform him into the psyche that was playing on his mind aka Birdman. Silver linings however were Zach Galifianakis, Edward Norton and Naomi Watts some fairly good acting there. Though how much can you rate a movie when you can predict every single intimate scene?

Do yourselves a favour and download this one.

Oh dear, Birdman.  Emperor's new clothes? An old story re-told in one take - been done before in Hitchcock's Rope!  And who ever said that Michael Keaton could act? Just because the film is about a nervous breakdown, doesn't mean that it's good Hollywood!
Original, entertaining. Theatre was full of old people bloated from dinner with stinky burps and farts. Emma Stone does a good job playing a depressed-rich-kid-smart-ass-that happens to be kinda hot.
I don't understand how this movie got good ratings. It was stupid & confusing. All about a self centered man who is afraid of being forgotten.
Horrible movie! Too bad there's nothing below 1/2 star to rate this one.
Stupid as hell! Depressing and boring!
worst show I have ever seen. walked out after 30 minutes. stupid, lack of storyline,no redeeming value.

It's been a while since I've genuinely enjoyed a movie from start to finish. Iñárritu's one-shot directorial style sets the stage for a poetically tragic film about an actor struggling to find relevance on the modern stage.

Michael Keaton, long forgotten to me, delivers such a personal, and masterful performance in what I can safely say is the best film I've watched in the last three years.

A movie which takes you by the arm and you get lost in the beauty that is cinema and in the many layers of this movie. Captured in a continuous long shot and accompanied with  exquisite drumming as background, it totally engulfs you 

The lead actors: Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, Emma Stone and Naomi Watts are absolutely brilliant with a stupendous supporting cast. 

Keaton is outstanding in one of his best performances and displays mettle which is Oscar worthy!! The entire cast and crew of the movie deserve a standing ovation for this piece of spell binding cinema!! 

If it's the scene of Keaton fighting with his alter ego or the explosive scene with his daughter, you can't miss this!! It makes you question your own life and is relatable at so many levels. This is not a movie but a piece of art!

Birdman isn't a movie you write a review about. It's a movie you have a conversation about. But here goes anyway...

Quite probably the film of the year. This is the kind of thing you can watch multiple times with increased meaning each viewing. So many deep motifs and meta elements (in this way it reminds me of Aronofsky's Black Swan.) The screenplay is rich, the performances are superb, and the unique cinematography creates an guided perspective that directs the experience while liberating the interpretation.
The acting is great. The score is great. The cinematography is great. I'd absolutely love this film if the ending didn't let me down.
Es imposible verla y no imaginarse a muchas glorias pasadas y su intento de ser relevantes hoy en día. Técnicamente es maravillosa.
It's definitely Iñárritu's best film... But that's not saying much.

The performances from Norton and Keaton were superb and the cinematography was unprecedented; however, this bleak, drawn-out story had trouble holding my attention and lacked overall best picture material.

31st December 2014

Birdman is the second film I got to in New York and I saw this one at the AMC25 theatre in Times Square and it's a film I've had tremendous hype for. And unfortunately for me I suck when it comes to going to films with no expectations. I just had to read all the reviews, watch the trailer twenty times and so on. And nine times out of ten it damages my enjoyment of the film.

Actor Riggan Thomson is most famous for his movie role from over twenty years ago of the comic book superhero Birdman in the blockbuster movie of the same name and its two equally popular sequels. His association with the role took over his life, where Birdman is more renowned than "Riggan Thomson" the actor. Now past middle age, Riggan is trying to establish himself as a true artist by writing, directing, starring in and co-producing with his best friend Jake what is his Broadway debut, an adaptation of a Raymond Carver story.

Birdman is just about as good as everyone is saying, which is praise worthy in itself. First thing to talk about is the direction by Alejandro González Iñárritu, no sorry, rather Emmanuel Lubeski, who is without doubt the best DP working today and here he delivers his finest achievement. This is any cinematographers wet dream.

It was originally Alejandro's plan to shoot the film in one seamless take. And if you know anything about filmmaking you will understand that is near on impossible. I say 'near impossible' because remarkably it has been pulled of before. Back in 2002 director Aleksandr Sokurov pulled this off managing to shoot his 99 minute film, Russian Ark, in one take without any cuts at all. Birdman, in my opinion does something just as impressive.

What director Iñárritu, DP Lubezki and editors Stephen Mirrione and Douglas Crise have done here is to shoot a series of long takes and masterfully blend them together creating, what appears, is one seamless take. If you're a film fanatic like myself you will probably pick upon where they might have cut but it's very hard to notice unless you're really paying attention to the logistics of the thing.

In a way this could be seen as a flaw in that the film's technical achievements could be used as a tool to distract you from the fact that film's storyline isn't as polished as its surface. But Birdman does a fine job in telling its story so I don't think it's too much of problem, other than maybe a few characters feeling underwritten. The acting in the film is first rate, everyone does superbly in their respective roles especially the man everyone's shouting about, Michael Keaton. What a comeback! My god.

The score is great which is entirely percussion based, really original and goes brilliantly with the film. I can't say it's the best film of the year but it's certainly up there. Birdman is a real achievement.
Another waste of good bandwidth. 2 hours of watching Keaton try to create a play while his daughter screws all the performers?? And this is up for an academy award, unreal.
Excellent film. Powerful acting. Great concept. Really makes you think. Very enjoyable.

Why the good reviews?! I was uninterested. The film was all over the place, had no real story line that took you in. It was boring.

The acting skills where probably amazing but  but really I just was waiting for something interesting to happen. Watched the film, but was hanging on by the skin of my teeth!

Geared towards the theatre bods. Not of interest if you just want to see a good film!
One of the most unique movies I've seen.
I have no words to describe this movie! It is that good!

A movie for actors, about acting, starring some really, *really* terrific actors.  Many of whom have personal experience starring in big-budget super-hero movies while also trying to maintain reputations as serious actors.  And to think, I had a choice tonight between this and 'Dumb and Dumber To', which is kind-of the point.  Grade A.
Everyone should watch this movie.
Slow and deals with humanity few experience: being an actor/star/celebrity.
Brilliantly shot, great performances from all lead actors (with the obvious shout out going to Keaton, Norton was a surprise), and all around interesting movie.
Everything about it is great... acting, story, directing. Killed it... and Raymond Carver.
I honestly don't get it. Like Keaton's performance, the way it was shot/edited, liked the "drum" soundtrack. But what was this movie about?

Off-the-wall, not for a casual movie night, but well executed filmmaking with a memorable performance by Michael Keaton as an actor formerly a star superhero on the big screen (Keaton himself starred in the first 2 Batman films, 1989 & 1992) now desperately scrambling to get a Broadway stage play off the ground. Much of the film is made of long, continuous camera shots that follow Keaton around as he tries to make this show his comeback from painful obscurity as a has-been celebrity. He also tries to make amends with his neglected family. The camera keeps rolling while following him around like a documentary but with minimal shaking, as he runs from from person to person and challenge to challenge. The ending leaves some room for interpretation, but whatever you conclude, this is definitely a journey through the psychological affects of being famous (at one time). It has some bizarre moments where we sometimes cross over into the mind apart from reality without any flag to mark reality and fantasy. It's not the standard fun flick, it has some dry humor to give it a lighthearted feel. is notably creative, well-acted, and gives deep characters that altogether present a commentary on the highs and lows of being a celebrity.

And the winner is . . . .  I haven't seen Whiplash yet (seeing it in an hour), but of those Oscar nominees I have seen, this is far and away the best. Funny, perfectly acted, gritty sets, excellent direction, gorgeous cinematography. Pretty perfect.
it left me laughing historically at some points due the enjoyment of what I don't understand

I really enjoyed the film. It's one of those movies you have to see at some point. It's just too different and creative to not be taken seriously.
Some of the monologues were classics, and could be quoted endlessly, which is no doubt why nerd critics fell in love with it.
However, the fractured nature of the film is a little much, and I suspect many people laud Birdman just because it's uncool not to. It was definitely flawed, albeit charmingly so. Highly recommended viewing, but not worth the hype.
O filme de Iñárritu  é como um exercício de estilo uma experiência emocional não tão inteligente quanto pensa que é.

Well acted, thought provoking film about a washed up actor, best known for playing a superhero, attempting a comeback on the Broadway stage.  Great cast and an interesting stream-of-consciousness narrative all told through the illusion of one continuous tracking shot.

Finally watched that one-shot masterpiece movie! Gripping, entertaining, with a great insight of what goes on behind the greatest Broadway and Hollywood scenes and actors. The idea of a single take/shot movie was a stroke of genius, perfectly fitting the continuous sequence of the movie and the dialogue. The screenplay contains such deep acumen and some thoughts of wisdom, so I particularly hope the movie gets the Academy Award for best original screenplay. Finally, although really needless to highlight this fact, Michael Keaton and Edward Norton truly gave Oscar worthy performances; profound and very vigorous. P.S. the certain projections made about critics was most appreciated and really spot on.
The "one take" approach pulls you in and keeps you there. The acting by the whole cast is some of the best I have ever seen...don't miss it.
Offensively indulgent.
Though its topic and drama as overall might be familiar, it's really enjoyable and refreshing.
When even Zach Galifianakis gives a respectable dramatic performance in a film, you have to think you're watching something pretty special.
This is a very unique, intense movie. Super creative, thoughtful, and amazingly acted. It often made me feel quite uncomfortable.

What truly makes Birdman a fantastic addition to this yr's nominees is in the manner in which Inárritu is able to extract astounding performances from the ensemble cast (with Keaton leading the pack) amidst the surreal world he creates in this movie...The line "Did you know Farrah Fawcett died the same day as Michael Jackson?", is what drives Keaton throughout the movie and is at the center of the theme being explored in this one...Edward Norton is just fantastic is his supporting actor gig, which kinda of takes me back to his Fight Club days..But what to say about Keaton's coming of age performance..Wow! Its like he's in some way playing himself in the movie after his Batman days; its a case of the makers getting the casting spot on...There are many moments in the movie where you think that probably this is the scene which gave him his nomination, nd no doubt he's leading the race this time...Moments b/w him nd Stone (who btw comes in with another top notch performance to land herself a first academy award nomination) provide some great minutes of cinema..AGI's (who's Mexican and not a Spaniard unlike last year's award winning visionary director alfonso cuaron) vision and character exploration is just impeccable and has taken the movie to another level...

Really enjoyed it, but I loved parts of it more than the whole. Michael Keaton was great. I loved his scenes with Emma (that last one almost had me in tears). Had quite a few laughs too. Cinematography was terrific and those long takes were just mesmerizing. Couldn't help but think of Aronofsky's The Wrestler while watching it though.

Filmed almost flawlessly. If you want to know what a single 1h:50m take for a movie "may" look like, this is what you should be watching. Interesting story and character depth. Nobody seems to be talking about the production aspect of Birdman.
Interesting on a structurally filmic level, but utterly catatonic/ boring.

In "Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)" former Batman star Michael Keaton plays Riggan Thomson, a has-been actor who used to play a superhero named Birdman in three successful Hollywood blockbusters. Now he aims to gain respect and recognition on Broadway, directing and starring in an adaptation of Raymond Carver's short story "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love".

The film follows Riggan through a painstaking process of rehearsals and drama both behind and in front of the curtain. He stars with his girlfriend Laura (Andrea Riseborough) and Broadway newcomer Lesley (Naomi Watts). One of his actors gets injured and has to be replaced on the spot by Mike (Edward Norris), a volatile but ingenious character actor of bigger fame than Riggan himself. Mike is also sleeping with Lesley, how else. Creative differences and conflict abound when two special egos collide. The play's producer, Riggan's lawyer Jake (Zach Galifianakis) is desperately trying to hold the production together. Among all the action is Riggan's teenaged daughter and current assistant Sam (Emma Stone), freshly out of rehab.

Riggan hears the voice of Birdman in his head. He uses supernatural powers of telekinesis on objects- only when he is by himself. The pressure to create something meaningful begins to overtake him. A deconstruction of his fragile psyche seems imminent. But he has so much to say. He needs to create, but does he have it in him?

This is the fifth feature from art house favorite Alejandro Gonzáles Iñárritu. I have found all of his movies fascinating, but often a bit tedious. "Babel" was especially dragging, if accomplished. I was from the start pleasantly surprised by the intensity of "Birdman". It's a mixture of drama, comedy and magical realism, all of which work together perfectly. But the experience that is this movie runs deeper and captivates absolutely.

Theater is always an interesting setting but here it's being utilized in its fullest capacity. The film is shot as if with one take like an evolved version Hitchcock's masterful "The Rope", the camera floats completely free as a bird, following the characters through the maze-like structure of the theater, relieving the viewer from an otherwise claustrophobic experience of the location. The picture never cuts, nor does the storytelling. "Birdman" film is a lot about dialog, and who says what and especially where in the setting is crucial; the theatre is like a Freudian interpretation of the movie's- or maybe Riggan's- psyche which we get to explore.

And then there's the atmosphere. We are definitely working somewhere within the subconscious. The subtly surreal reality of the movie borrows from the greatest works of Woody Allen, David Cronenberg and Martin Scorsese, but stands on its own. The script reflects Raymond Carver in just the right way, considering. The actors are all superb, the Broadway a character in itself. The soundtrack is a showcase of minimalism, an occasional jazzy drum solo elevates key scenes, telling us that we are experiencing a deeper level of the dreamscape whose symbols we are invited to decipher.

"Birdman" is magic. It's unique, seductive and special, a masterpiece that confirms Iñárritu as not only a talented but genius filmmaker.

Birdman is an ambitious feat that completes to near-perfection. It is a dazzling piece of film grasping the viewer by the collar unceremoniously and it refuses to let go for days. The imprint this movie leaves is fantastic, and can be testament to the brilliant and risky direction, the stunning acting going beyond believability, and the rhythmic tone-setting music. There is little to fault, and more to admire. Birdman flirts with breaking the fourth wall, it flirts with real-magic, and in doing so, it is able to portray the chaotic calamity that dwells in the protagonist's mind. Alejandro G has created a modern day master piece. Michael Keaton steals the show and is convincing every step of the way. Birdman, in its own right, is a masterpiece of film-making, and is a center-piece for admiration and further learning.

O que realmente tornou para mim o filme completamente apaixonante e absurdamente diferenciado é o cuidado com os diversos aspectos de uma produção. Em Birdman, jamais é esquecido que os elementos em cena possuem uma função narrativa e cinematográfica simultânea. Assim, desde os diálogos afiados que brincam com a sonoridade das palavras e as referências cinematográficas e visuais com jogos de objetos, espelhos, imagens, cores, fluxos psicológicos, ritmo e choques de perspectiva, Iñarritu cria uma história interessantíssima e ambígua que introjeta nos problemas mentais do protagonista o cinema, o teatro, a interpretação e a imitação da vida, proporcionando um sentido real para o discurso metalinguístico, o que é absolutamente sensacional de se ver. E eu nem vou falar aqui das obviedades como as atuações excepcionais, o falso plano único (e suas consequências no ritmo psicológico), etc.

Como sempre digo, de tempos em tempos, algo muito bacana acontece na sétima arte. Esse ano é um deles, ao meu ver. Achei fenomenal.

Birdman is a case of The Emperor's New Clothes. It's clearly naked. Everyone can see that it's naked, but they're all afraid to say that it's naked for fear that the people standing next to them will say they don't "get it". 

Well, I'm sorry, but I don't get it. Not because it's too deep, or surreal, or because of all the long tracking shots with drummers inexplicably in the middle of the scene, but because there's no actual substance here. There's a lot of muddling about, a lot of self-reflection and even a little grandstanding, but in the end the characters have not become any more fleshed-out, the story hasn't moved in any particular direction, and the audience is being dared to not like the movie. By inserting the evil critic character and the scene immediately following her comparison of  "celebrity versus Actor", the movie essentially says, "if you don't like this piece of high art, then you're just a heathen who likes Michael Bay movies." 

Well, I'm neither. Michael Bay is horrible, but "Birdman" is bland.

While I can say that every actor gives a fantastic performance, I can also say they're not actually DOING anything in those performances. Their characters are made of particle board. The plot is thin-to-nonexistent. The "message" is nothing special. The moral never comes into focus. 

I'm telling you: It's okay not to like "Birdman". Really. It's okay not to "get it". You're still cool, and you're not making yourself look foolish or unhip. There's nothing to "get" here. It's just a big ball of directorial ego wrapped in brown paper. 

Mark Twain said a "classic" is "A book which people praise and don't read." Well, I predict "Birdman" will become a classic in that vein. It will be a movie that people praise, but don't actually, deep-down, enjoy. However, because the movie flat-out tells people that not liking it means you're a schlock-loving peasant, people will maintain the dissimulation.

Birdman is a bit of a strange film in that I both liked it and disliked it simultaneously.  It tells the story of Michael Keaton who plays a washed up actor trying to make it big with his broadway play.  His daughter treats him like an asshole, his costar kind of IS an asshole, and his attempt to reinvent himself seems to be failing.  

The film tells the story linearly, but in a way where time jumps forward without any specific indication.  The camera work is fluid, relying on a constant long-take approach facilitated by steadicam and giving the film a dream-like quality.  The acting is quite brilliant, with Galifinakis, Stone, and Norton really standing out in my opinion.   The soundtrack is also fantastic, featuring some really groovy jazz tracks and some brilliant classical tracks including Ravel's Pavane (a personal favorite).  So why do I dislike the film?  Well...  

The subject matter is, in my opinion, fairly shallow.  There's a lot of emphasis on some deeper spiritual/philosophical meaning that feels patched together rather than properly explored.  The long-take steadicam work is well done, but I found it unnecessary and distracting, waiting for cuts instead of paying attention to the film.  Everyone in the film is barely relateable, coming across as shallow and self-absorbed.  The film strives to be surrealistic, a style I love a lot, but something about the combination of elements made this film feel like it was using surrealism as a crutch to obfuscate the otherwise thin story.  

TL;DR - 5/10
I'm probably going to be crucified for my review, but that's fine.  This film is simultaneously great and horrible, but that doesn't mean you won't end up really enjoying it.  I highly recommend checking it out at least once to get your own opinion, because although I'm not the film's biggest fan, I do consider it a worthwhile film, especially in today's relatively shit cinematic landscape.

While innovative director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu has given us many brilliant films before, this is the first time he's delved into the genre of comedy, that too black comedy. His ambitious attempt to make the movie appear to be shot in one seamless motion for most of it (with the help of numerous retakes and proper edits) certainly works to the movie's advantage; it makes us a part of the lead protagonist's (Thomas Riggan's) inescapable reality, much like life. But more importantly, it takes us into the mind of the director himself.

In a bird's eye view, the film may appear to be a critique on the ever-growing trend of superhero movies, and the politics of show business in general. But essentially, it's a satire on human traits like ego and ambition, our constant search and struggle to feel relevant and important in this world; many of us forsake everything else in order to achieve this. We can see this through Riggan's character, who is conflicted between the once-achieved stardom through his Birdman movies and his present, where he is adapting the work of an author (Carver) because of whom he became an actor in the first place. Birdman vs Carver - On one side, we have Birdman, which gained him the love and affection of audiences worldwide, and on the other side, we have Raymond Carver, which represents the kind of intellectual work which usually gets critical acclaim. So, he is stuck between the two, internally struggling to decide which one to choose; he ambitiously wants the love of both audiences and critics alike.

Other than being a black comedy, the movie also falls into the genre of Magical Realism (movies like 'Pan's Labyrinth', 'Life of Pi', 'Midnight in Paris'). Riggan keeps hearing this voice speaking to him, and can perform telekinesis and levitation whenever he wants. This Birdman is just the personification of his inner ego and the larger-than-life image he once had; Riggan wants to soar through the sky. And ego's personification here (Birdman) draws parallels to Icarus (who flew too close to the sun with wings made of feathers and wax).

Other than the amazing screenplay, the dialogues are the film's biggest strength; they are sharp-witted and hilarious, and form the backbone of the film. After that, it's brilliant performances given by Michael Keaton and Edward Norton; they are pure delight to watch. Zach Galifianakis also does a good job, and the four ladies (Emma Stone, Naomi Watts, Andrea Riseborough and Amy Ryan) look and perform terrific. Emmanuel Lubezki's camera-work and Antonio Sanchez's drum score certainly help the movie feel like it does. Without Lubezki's assistance, the apparent single shot feat couldn't have been achieved; the movie looks spectacular.

It's interesting to notice how many of the actors have association with superhero movies; Keaton was Tim Burton's Batman (this is what makes his character self-referential), Norton was the Incredible Hulk, and Stone was Gwen Stacy in the contemporary Spiderman series. On top of that, we see that Riggan's character has many similarities with the character Ed he's playing in the stage play within the movie. And the few aspects of Ed's life which aren't there in Riggan's life become fulfilled towards the second half of the movie. All these parallels help in blurring the lines between fiction and reality, which makes the movies quite psychotic, and at the same time, fascinating.

Overall, the movie tackles with so many captivating themes that a simple review like mine is not enough to discuss all of them. All I can say is, for people who get what the director is going for, the movie is sure to stay etched in their minds for a long time, and forms an important topic for many round-table discussions. 'Birdman' is a mesmerizing experience not to be missed by ardent movie lovers.

-------------------------SPOILERS-------------------------

People who might be left confused by ending - We see Riggan get up from his bed and getting onto the window. Then, we see his daughter Sam coming into the room, looking outside the window. She looks up and smiles. The movie ends there.

My interpretation is: No, Riggan didn't jump off the window and try to kill himself again. We don't see him jumping, we just see him standing there. Maybe he was just enjoying the view of the city (world) with his new-found perspective. He's done with the inner struggle, his mind is at peace now, and his act got him the feeling of relevance he craved for, so there's no need to kill himself. When Sam looks out the window, she looks up and smiles; this is when Riggan's metaphoric fantasy meets Sam's physical reality. Sam sees him flying and soaring through the sky. All this time, Riggan was the only one who was in these delusions of fantasy. He had the larger-that-life image 20 years ago, when he was popular with his Birdman movies. Sam was too young at that time. Now with the new-found fame and acclaim all around, Sam finally sees him the way he has always seen himself - as the majestic hero soaring above everyone.

"Birdman" directed by Alenjandro Gonzalez is a mixture of masterful film making with tremendous performance from Michael Keaton , Edward Norton and Emma Stone. The picture got some other stellar performances but we will come to that later.To begin with MIchael Keaton has given one of his career best performances with a single word - "Range" . That was one hell of a mixture of comedy to extreme drama without a sense of getting over the top. You could literally hide that character in mask and get the same viscous performance one would imagine. The supporting performance of Edward Norton was brilliant and for a moment during the first act of the film I thought Norton was giving a stellar performance but the most under appreciated performance will probably be Emma Stone but she was right at the heart of the picture. There were many things to make this film work and it required Emma Stone's character to tie them at many places and she nailed. Now when you get stellar performances from your great cast and mix that with one sensational edit which makes this film play out as a play. That is a very subtle metaphor to execute and for that the director and the writer Alenjandro needs to be praised. Not only did he bring out tremendous performances from the main cast but he tied them together along with the editor and presented the whole picture as a play with three acts. Much of what I appreciate about the directing skills is because of that. The screenplay on it's own however lacked a bit of "special" to make it all great and it by itself did not have the quality of exuding emotions if one were to read it. It's a brilliant one but it does contain some unnecessary scenes specially when one considers it as a character based drama. So if that would have been tightened the review would have all stars. The music needs to be appreciated and not just the composing of it but the application of it which is why the director along with the composer must be praised . The music does tell a story and not just an underlying factor. But the real star of the picture and it's quite obvious from the look of it is Lubezski. Again the director requires recognition for shot composition but the way the cinematography morphed the story was brilliant. You can consider this 2 hour picture as one long shot and that applicability was brilliant. The lights and the focus of it all was done through the cinematography. It is one of the rare occasion that the cinematography brings out a brilliant performance of the actors. It reflected the whole story. This mexican pcokethouse is actually one of the greatest if not the greatest cinematographer of this era. Everything about that art was brilliant and we don't know whose choice it was but it was seamless.

Michael Keaton in the character of Riggan is a former movie star celebrity who tries to re-launch his dying-fame career as an actor through the "spot light" of theater. 
According to the critics of Broadway, the stage is a world that doesn't belong to him; a lucky made movie star that has no "Classical" preparation or stage experience.

Thanks to the previous successful movie franchise 'BirdMan' had no problems getting his foot through the door of Broadway, however the fictional character of the "Birdman" has made him the shadow of himself.

In a modern world, where "dreaming" and expressing is oppressed by the power of finances, and social and personal relations are lubricated with failures and false promises, success and determination is the cure to all.
Guided by strong commitment can he finally find that lost "self" and "global" recognition and prove wrong the rest of the world?

The story, in an obvious sense, deals with issues such as the desire for artistic validation, creative satisfaction, redemption and the sacrifices made in the name of art. But this movie also takes a satirical look at mindless pop culture and pretentious art house culture, taking shots at both in equal measure. Surreal and effective! As a recap, Alejandro Innaritu's previous works include Amores Perros, 21 Grams, Babel - a 'trilogy' of long films involving multiple storylines, the first two of which worked for me. I haven't watched his last one, Biutiful, but Birdman is one of those rare films which are magic! The conception, the craft and the execution all just hit the spot and produce magic. What's amazing is Innaritu came up with its 'Broadway-backstage story' as well, aside from producing and directing. Michael Keaton is great in the lead role as a very human middle-age actor in need of renewal. The music is unique too.. it's not Gustavo Santaolalla this time, but it's just lots of minimalist sounds - brushsticks on snare drums and hi hats; evoking the flow and taking the viewer from one room to another. Yes, that's the amazing thing this director did - film long takes with a single camera!

This joke of a movie is going to appeal to a limited number of people. After watching the previews, I saw NO REASON to see Birdman. A friend of mine went and raved about it. Being mentioned for and receiving awards, curiosity got the best of me. Should have went with my gut. 
     Forget the acting. Yes, you can have great acting in a bad movie. Will Smith in Six Degrees of Separation comes to mind. Nobody stands out that much in Birdman to make it worth seeing. There is a moment of an entertaining movie here and there buried beneath all the gibberish, but not enough to keep me entertained for 2 hours. That's right: TWO HOURS! 
     If you take actors seriously, and think their lives that go from multi-millionaire to person trying to get it all back after squandering it is interesting, by all means, this movie is for you. 
     Birdman doesn't make you feel sorry for the lead. It doesn't make him a likable person. He's not even a very insightful guy. He's merely a man who's been so wrapped up in himself for such a long time, that now that everything is collapsing, is having something of a breakdown. It's a selfish douche, his screwed up daughter (surprise), a jerk of a critic (unique), a broadway douchey actor (there's plenty of them), and a cast of low self esteem people ranting about nothing, and I mean nothing, important, for TWO HOURS. Then cap it off with a stupid ending. Aaaand curtain. It's not worth seeing at any point, in my opinion.

I'm Birdman! Wait, Crayola Steve is Birdman. Oh wait that's Michael Keaton, wait Michael Keaton was Batman, what the heck is going on here! My review of Birdman right now.

Birdman (or the Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) is directed and written by Alejandro G. Iñárritu and stars Michael Keaton, Zach Galifiankis, Edward Norton and Emma Stone and tells the story of Riggan Thomas, who in the 1980s played the popular superhero Birdman. Now he is a washed up actor trying to gain success once more by directing, writing and staring in his broadway play. But things are complicated Riggan begins to hear the voice of Birdman.

Birdman is a holy original and masterful piece of work from Alejandro G. Iñárritu. This features the best ensemble cast of 2014, some of the best editing I've ever seen and is one of the best movies of 2014. If you get the chance to see it, don't miss out.

There's been a lot of Oscar buzz surrounding Michael Keaton's performance and oh my god does he deserve it! Michael Keaton is at his absolute best in this movie and is perfectly casted. He pretty much plays himself since in the 80s he played Batman and in this movie he played Birdman. It's almost a spoof and it works so great. Keaton here plays a very wounded, sad character who might or might not be losing his mind. In the quiet moment is where Keaton is able to shine and show off his acting chops, something I haven't seen in a very long time. This is one of the best performances of 2014 and he's the frontrunner to win the Oscar for sure!

In supporting roles are Edward Norton, Emma Stone and Zach Galifiankis. Norton plays Mike Shiner, a method actor who comes on the set of the play and begins to cause some major problems in the production. He is so freaking great in this movie. He basically plays a parody of himself, Norton in real life was been known to have a temper and hard to work with (he got fired from The Incredible Hulk). His interaction with Michael Keaton is some of the best chemistry I've seen in a while since they don't ever see eye to eye. He definitely deserves his Oscar nomination without a doubt. 

Then Emma Stone gives the best performance of her career as Riggan's daughter, Sam. She is this rebel character who isn't the best working with people. Her chemistry with Keaton is out of control, they work so well together but it's the scenes she shares with Edward Norton where she truly shines. Stone is one of the best actresses working right now, she and proves it in this movie. And holy crap Zach Galifiankis is freaking great in a small role of Riggan's agent.

But all credit has to be given to the director of the film. His direction here is so strong. He creates the illusion that this movie is just one log continuous shot. A lot of the movie was shot in ridiculous long takes and with amazing editing, it looks like it's all shot in one whole take. It adds to the feeling of the film. Characters are constantly moving around the stage, front and back and you get this sense of what it's like in these small halls. The camera moving right in front of them or moving in the back of them at all times it was absolutely immersive. Though you can tell where some of the parts were cut for the next scene, it's still amazing to see these characters moving around.

And the screenplay, oh my god, the screenplay is brilliant. It's completely original in every sort of way, I've never seen a movie like this before. This movie actually a lot to say about hollywood. It tells and shows you everything that's wrong with hollywood today. It mentions big stars like Robert Downey Jr., and Woody Harrelson so we know they are living in the year 2014. It mocks people who just go to see big blockbusters for the action and visual effects and my personal favorite, what's wrong with critics. There's a reason I don't like being called a critic and the movie tells you why. Some critics don't even watch the movie, they just want to find big or professional words to slap on a DVD cover. They don't even look at the structure, performances, or meaning of anything it's just an easy way to get money. This was my favorite aspect of the movie.

The music is also great, I loved the score in this movie. It's a very jazzy score with drums playing for the most part. At times you actually see the man playing the drums in various scenes and that was awesome as well.

I'm not jumping on the bandwagon when I say this movie is nearly perfect. It really is. The performances are great, the directing is great, the editing is nearly perfect and the script is even better than those. Birdman would have completely been on my best of 2014 video because:

Birdman gets an A+.

A spectacular piece of virtuoso cinema that impresses not only for its remarkable technical achievement (Lubezki reached heavens with that jaw-dropping "forged" long-take), but also for being an incredibly well-constructed (and hilarious) character study with Michael Keaton in a magnificent career-defining performance.
A film that is shot in one long take deserves to be seen. Wait, I had almost forgotten: Keaton and Norton's performances are astonishing!
A unique film with powerful performances.

Alejandro González Iñárritu, el director de las obras maestras "Amores Perros", "21 Grams", "Babel" y "Biutiful", nos entrega su nueva obra maestra llamada "Birdman  O la Inesperada Virtud de la Ignorancia", una película formalmente sorprendente acerca de un actor encasillado en un papel de superhéroe que decide montar una obra de teatro de Raymond Carver.  El genial  fotógrafo Emmanuel Lubetzski nos logra engañar haciéndonos pensar que toda la película fue filmada en plano secuencia para tratar de meternos en una meta-experiencia teatral y así poder capturar la mejor actuación de la carrera de Michael Keaton, un actor encasillado en el papel de un superhéroe.  Keaton está rodeado de soberbias actuaciones, actores y personajes, ente los que se cuentan a Edward Norton, Zack Galifianakis, Naomi Watts, Emma Stone, Amy Ryan y Andrea Risenborough.  Más allá de una mirada crítica al mundo de la actuación o al comercialismo en el cine, "Birdman" es una impresionante película que no le teme a la experimentación, a la innovación y a las estructuras de género.  Todo un clásico instantáneo.

Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) was famous as the Birdman. He has now taken his savings and invested it in a Broadway play based on the works of Raymond Carver. Riggan is haunted by his past. He hears the voice and character of Birman in his head taunting him... It is like his Lady Macbeth. The show's previews are a disaster, despite the presence of wunder-kind Mike (Edward Norton) to share his stage, and Riggan struggles with the challenges of both the production and keeping a grip on reality. Birdman is an impressive visual journey. Though the story is a bit bonkers at time, it is also very interesting and the performances are quite compelling, especially that of Edward Norton. Its editing ensues that that it almost appears as one single take, which is simultaneously compelling and distracting. ] Intellectually, it explores the nature of celebrity with its tongue-in-cheek casting and commentary, however, there is also much about the role of theatrical art.

Magical realism, if you will, and at its most visceral, guided by endless tracking shots down backstage corridors, starring a man who can move and destroy items with only his mind.  That man is Riggan Thomas (Michael Keaton), an aging Hollywood star who struck success with a series of superhero films (he was Birdman).  Now, he is trying to redeem himself by writing and directing a version of a Raymond Carver short story for Broadway - but everything is falling apart, himself included.  That's the plot, briefly, but it is difficult to convey the force with which director Iñárritu and the cast throw everything at the viewer.  As the camera glides along, so too do various ideas and associations get thrust into your stream of consciousness. Sure, we think about Keaton as an ex-superhero whose career is winding down and Norton as a possibly intense and difficult to work with asshole.  But questions of truth, performance, reality, and fantasy (not to mention problematic psychological breaks) are never far from the forefront.  Shot in a month with incredibly long takes and then edited in two weeks (if I've got my facts right), the result is nothing short of amazing.  Keaton impresses as a man just barely holding on (to everything) and Norton, Naomi Watts, Emma Stone, Andrea Riseborough, and Zach Galifianakis manage to keep the emotional intensity of the picture at a fever pitch in support.  And just when you thought there was no way to end the picture without copping out, Iñárritu teases the audience with numerous possibilities and manages one that works.  A tour de force.

Birdman is an odd mixture of psychedelic introversion and hard bitten reality, vacillating wildly between the two states without really giving you time to adjust. Broadway actor and director Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) is living in the past, man, or rather the past in the form of a giant hallucinatory birdman is living in him. Once upon a time, he used to be said Birdman, star of three epic superhero films and Gen X darling of the screen. Now, that's history and he can't come to terms with it. Who could when there's a giant bird living in your head?

This film drags you with gritty realism through the dressing rooms and back streets of New York's world of theatre, most of it not very pretty at all and much of it produced in what seems to be one long documentary-style, follow-me-with-the-camera-as-I-do-whatever-it-is-I'm-doing take. Which is clearly impossible to manage without careful scripting and repeated efforts to get it right, but that's obviously how it's meant to feel. It's on the 'live' stage, however, that the film's most compelling moments occur. The acting is delivered with an intensely manic vibe and features some gruelling interaction between Keaton, Ed Norton and Naomi Watts, with some equally powerful backstage dramatic scenes involving those three plus the likes of Emma Stone and Zach Galifianakis.

For me, the most resonant chord echoing powerfully throughout the film is the metatextual, unspoken comment on Keaton's own career. After his unforgettable performance as Beetlejuice in 1988, Keaton agreed to play Batman in the following year's eponymous film, once again under the direction of Tim Burton. He reprised the role in 1992's 'Batman Returns' and was meant to appear as the Dark Knight for a third time in 1995's 'Batman Forever'. But Burton was dropped as director for that project and Keaton followed him through the exit door...and has never been seen again in anything remotely important. Until now, that is. Clearly, Birdman = Batman, in case you needed the dots joined for you.

This is a film that is really two stories in one. On the surface, it's an abrasive account of the shallowness and superficiality that pervades professional theatre, of the massive egos that occupy its spaces, of the dizzying highs and the terrifying lows that come with the territory, of the bitterness and bewilderment of once having been someone and now being no one. Beneath that, though, it's the story of a man with something that lives deep within him, defining him and only emerging slowly as the film progresses, rising eventually and powerfully from the ashes like the proverbial phoenix. The final scene, in which Sam Thomson (Stone) rushes to the window to look for her father, looking down to where his earthly body clearly lies then looking up to where his alter-ego has evidently taken flight, all without showing us anything but the emotions that pass across her captivating face, is simplicity, brilliance and poignancy all rolled into one.

Birdman deserves to win several Oscars later this month, and it is nominated for nine. There is some stiff competition, as always, but I'm hoping that Michael Keaton, at least, can pull off the big one after a much vaunted career of frustrations that spans my entire adult life. He is a superb actor and this is a superb film.

I have mixed feelings about this movie. I was blown away by the revolutionary directorial style. Scene transitions are so seamless that the whole movie seems to be one long shot by a single camera. I found myself suddenly realizing the story had move ahead in time, sometime minutes, sometimes hours or sometimes weeks. That was amazing. 

I found it disturbing that the film so accurately captured how it feels to be teetering on the ragged edge of sanity where it is hard to tell the difference between real and unreal. I had the unfortunate experience of having an Adderall  prescription for ADHD that sent me to place like that. Unlike the character in the story, I knew I was in trouble and didn't believe the unreal things I saw and held on 5 long days for the medicine to wear off. This movie brought back that terrible experience in realistic detail. So, if you want to know what it feels like to go crazy, this is the film for you.

On the surface this seems like an old story - the comeback of a forgotten hero - but it is made fresh in a new and interesting way. The acting is spectacular too with truly gifted actors giving their very best performances.

I think this movie will win the Oscar, not because it is entertaining to the general public, but because it is a revolutionary movie in the movie industry. This could be a new "Citizen Kane." 

However, I think the average moviegoer will not like it. If your preference in movies runs in the categories of action, romance or family friendly then stay away.

?"Birdman" is a rarity these days  - a genuinely fresh and original movie. It works as a black comedy and a family drama. It also works as a social satire, fantasy and unique look into the workings of a Broadway play. It has one of the best ensemble casts of the year and is filmed in a way like no other movie you've seen.

It is a comeback piece for long-forgotten actor Michael Keaton ?who plays Riggan Thomson, a washed up actor who was once famous for playing a superhero called Birdman in the early 1990s (which makes it seem as Keaton is playing himself) who is attempting a comeback directing and starring in a Broadway play with the movie's events unraveling in the days leading up to the play's opening night. Riggan is a borderline-crazy, haunted soul dreading his existence and battling his own ego and alter ego Birdman (who speaks in a deep voice reminiscent to Batman). 

The movie is a great acting showcase particularly for Keaton in the kind of flashy comeback role that critics and Oscar voters love. My favorite performance from the movie, however, has to be Edward Norton in a very different performance as Mike an eccentric last minute replacement actor who gives Riggan the run for his money. He always seems the utterly crazy one in Riggan's presence. Emma Stone is also good but for the most part true to her form as Riggan's former junkie daughter who is also his assistant. Her performance is elevated only by a long monologue where she preaches her dad. Cast also includes an almost unrecognizable Zach Galifianakis as Riggan's lawyer and best friend, Naomi Watts as an actress making her Broadway debut who is Norton's love interest, Andrea Riseborough as another actress who is Riggan's girlfriend and Amy Ryan as his ex-wife. Watts and Riseborough's characters feel at times awash in the movie's midst and are somewhat underdevelopment especially with a mid-movie plot development involving the two ladies - that's probably the movie's only quibble.  

The movie is a landmark achievement for director Alejandro González Iñárritu ("Amores Perros", "21 Grams", "Babel") with the movie shot in a way as if it is all one unedited continuous take (kudos to cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki right off his Oscar for "Gravity" last year, which really works well with the movie. ? The drum-based soundtrack by Antonio Sanchez is also groundbreaking and suits the film's vibe perfectly. It is shame the Academy didn't deem it eligible due to it sampling some classical music. And then there's that movie's final shot that keeps you thinking. Nominated for 9 Oscars: Picture, Director, Actor (Keaton), Supporting Actor (Norton), Supporting Actress (Stone), Original Screenplay, Cinematography, Sound Editing, Sound Mixing.

While watching 'Birdman' I was constantly waiting to be dazzled and impressed but sadly that moment never arrives in a satisfying way. Without those two aspects to lean on, 'Birdman' lays an egg in terms of both story and actual direction. The characters feel like cardboard cut-outs, they are too familiar and predictable, and some of the dialogue in the film just plain hurt my ears. This is one film about the entertainment industry and art which can be skipped, as it doesn't bring anything new to the table except some never needed 'teaching'. This acclaimed film is a bizarre and unique work.  Great credit goes to director Alejandro González Iñárritu who really put together an altogether new type of film to tell a dark comedic narrative.  Michael Keaton being cast as Riggan Thompson was inspired, who could possible connect closer to this role than the man who played Batman twice?  describing the real nature of the film and its appeal, one has to recognize who the TRUE audience of this film is.  No question about it, this is a film for actors and people in the entertainment industry.  The average person who doesn't act on stage or film can get a glimpse at some of the narcissistic traits of the principles in this film, but it isn't really a film for everyone.  It has a lot of great parts to it, but what the film fails to do is truly set up a protagonist you really want to root for.  Ed Norton plays a character who is both scene stealing and undeniably unlikeable.  But each of the principle performers are given an opportunity to shine.  Emma Stone, Naomi Watts, Norton, Keaton, even Galifianakis, they all have very great scenes to show their tremendous skill.  The film asks a few industry questions to stew on, like the conflict between the art and the celebrity. Understandably such a film was well received in its industry.  But film maker navel gazing doesn't necessarily resonate with the average person.  The film is a solid R film, not family entertainment.  As a dark comedy it is not laugh out loud funny, but still a solid work worthy of some acclaim.  A singular piece, I doubt you'll see another film like it.

Michael Keaton playing an actor who at one point was at the top of the box office in his role in one of the original superhero movies, is so close to reality that it has to be more than a coincidence. This was a  conscious decision on the part of director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu, to cast the man who played the original (modern day) Batman and basically kicked off the Super Hero blockbuster genre. And I love that Keaton did it, being so derivative of his own life. 
With a star studded cast, everybody brought their A game to Birdman. Edward Norton plays a pretentious broadway actor, and a dick, as he tends to do so well and does again here. But you can't help but like him. Emma Stone is probably one of the only chicks out their that can make looking like a drug riddled skank look so good, and turns in a sterling performance here as Keaton's daughter, Sam. Then of course Michael Keaton is just fantastic in his role as Riggan, aka Birdman. I love the way Keaton's brain looks like it is ticking over as you see his character trying to deal and understand with the problems of running a broadway show and facing his own self doubts. He is deservedly up for an Oscar in this role. 
But probably the most impressive thing about this movie, is the way that it is shot. Made to look like the entire movie is all one continuous take (save a few time lapses here and there) the cinematography and directing is just flat out unbelievable. I have never seen anything like this, and for a style that could potentially make things feel slower, Inarritu instead brings a fast paced energy with his well choreographed shots. Scenes seamlessly blending in and out of each other as the players come and go, highlighting how stressful things are becoming. If this doesn't own Best Cinematography at the Oscars, I will be dumbfounded. And I like that it hasn't been a selling point for the film, normally movies that take the 'one shot' approach use it as a gimmick and the story lacks for it. Bit that is definitely not the case here. With a spectacular script, Birdman is one of the best movies I have seen in a long time. It's ambiguous ending may have a few people scratching their heads, but I like it. It's one of those endings, not unlike Prisoners or Inception that will make for great conversations as people compare their own interpretations of it.
You must see this in cinemas.

I think it may still be a top-three front runner for Best Picture. Having seen Boyhood and Whiplash, two movies I rated 9/10, this is a distant third in my books. Whiplash was just great. Boyhood was stunning in that it had that gimmick about the 12 years and it was actually moving. Birdman has its own gimmick: the one-take shot thing. I thought it an unnecessary and detrimental gimmick, but reading up, I guess the emphasis was that theater is one take so they did this movie about theater with the "one take." Bleh. Birdman is narcissistic. In a fit of self-righteousness, it has decided to eschew current trends, scorn social media, and travail constantly towards being "real." In its mind, the film is a martyr, a revolutionist standing up for what needs to be said. It seems to think that saying something loud enough and long enough constitutes taking a brave, bold stand. In reality, the film is simply a regurgitation of popular nonconformist sentiments. The filmmakers aren't fighting for the current state of entertainment, they are fighting for Birdman. In turn, the film is arrogant, egotistical, pretentious, heavy-handed, self-centered, abrasive, and in the end, to use a label that Riggan Thomson hates, lackluster.

Lackluster is the last thing the filmmakers of Birdman were attempting to accomplish. The film couldn't be any more in your face. The cinematography by the unparalleled Emmanuel Lubezki is, well, unparalleled. There isn't a single other DP in the business who can do what Lubezki does with such precision. The film is shot to look like one continuous take, an accomplishment that is very impressive indeed. But much like the film itself, it's technically stunning but ultimately distracting and empty. I get the reasoning behind the camera work, in an attempt to merge the worlds of film and stage, one shot more accurately symbolizes the theatre. But it does not service the best interest of the story. It proves noticeably distracting. Instead of "making you feel like you're actually there," the technique ushers in a certain level of detachment. I didn't feel like I was present during the film, I just felt like I was being dragged along for the bumpy ride. But of course, director Alejandro González Iñárritu would prefer to incapacitate his audience with over-the-top filmmaking techniques to hide the fact that Birdman is a cold and haughty film, almost entirely devoid of human emotions.

After the cinematography, the performances are the film's second calling card. And once again, they are often magnificent fiascos. There is an abundance of great acting to be found here, but it is so often misplaced and ineffective. The acting in the film feels very much like the theatre. It has all the bombast of the British acting style, but little of the finesse and potency of "the method." Iñárritu would much rather show Riggan thrashing around his dressing room, or Riggan and Edward Norton's Mike Shiner wrestling in their underwear, than to actually have his characters experience moments of reflection. The movie huffs and puffs and assumes that the best way to impact an audience is to scream in their face.

Once again, that's not to say that there aren't terrific performances in Birdman. Michael Keaton does some wonderful acting (the more Michael Keaton the better!), but the performance is often pointed in the wrong direction. Emma Stone does some of her best work here, with one particularly show-stopping monologue. I've been waiting for another performance from Andrea Riseborough ever since she stole the show in Oblivion, and she is a stand-out once again. Zack Galifianakis also does a wonderful job keeping his character grounded. And while I wasn't entirely a fan of the aimlessness of Mike Shiner, I am 100% in accord with those who lobby for an Oscar nomination for Ed Norton. He deserves it.

I can't comprehend how anyone who earlier this year enjoyed Guardians of the Galaxy could simultaneously say that they enjoy Birdman. The two films are diametrically opposed. Now, I have just as much distain for The Amazing Spider-Man 2 and Transformers 4 as the next guy. But I also have no patience for the bitter and broad strokes the film paints with. Once the cinematography and acting are looked past, the movie is trying to say something. The film is very much about the Hollywood/Broadway divide. The real art and acting invention of the theatre, versus the celebrity and explosions of the movies. In the most insulting and pretentious moment of the film, Iñárritu sardonically points to his audience and says, "People? They love blood! They love action! Not this talky, philosophical bullshit." A comment like that applies directly to Birdman and its audience, and it is really, gratingly pompous. The movie can shake its fist at excessive superhero filmmaking all it wants, but it has absolutely nothing new to say and certainly no groundbreaking commentary to provide.

On a side note about the whole superhero thing, Birdman thinks that referencing actual current actors and movies is a stroke of brilliance, that it somehow gives the film another point on the "masterpiece" plane. Riggan makes note of Robert Downey Jr. making billions of dollars with Iron Man and The Avengers. And yet, the film casts Emma Stone who, obviously, played Gwen Stacy very recently. Taken a step further, Ed Norton actually shared the same cinematic universe as Downey Jr.'s Iron Man! So, if The Avengers exist in Birdman's world, then so too must The Incredible Hulk, and so too must Edward Norton. So who the heck is this Mike Shiner character? Now, I'm sure that if I liked this movie, I would love these references. It's all one big meta joke, right!? Right? ...Right.

Then there is another thematic layer of Riggan himself. Throughout the film, Riggan is constantly fighting "The Birdman," the personification of big Hollywood, his ego, and the very superhero movies the film detests. But in typical fashion, the movie has no idea what to say with its pulpit. Towards the end of the film, it appears as if Riggan finally gives in to the Birdman. He accepts his ability to be a movie star over toiling on the stage. Or does he? The movie quickly throws (what I understand to be) its symbolism right out the window. It feels like the film chooses each scene based on optimal Oscar bait potential, and less in adherence to plot.

The following paragraphs will contain spoilers, be warned... As the film draws to its first close, Riggan prepares for opening night of his play. In the performance's finale scene, he is supposed to shoot himself in the head (fake gun and blood, of course). Instead, Riggan decides to actually shoot himself on stage. And he does. But when he does, the film finally breaks from its continuous shot. It goes into a dream-like scene, with painfully ham-fisted symbolism. In a daze, we see a Broadway stage, but instead of actors, we see Transformers and superheroes battling it out on the stage. In the moment when Riggan shoots himself, he becomes popular, a sensation, he goes viral. In the fallout, stage and screen have merged. Riggan has spent the entire movie striving towards his perception of the legitimacy of the theatre, only to have his efforts rewarded with a "celebrity" style reaction. The film's ideology, once again, becomes baffling. Is Iñárritu trying to say that popularity is what's truly wrong with Hollywood? And if so, that is an infuriating mindset that completely disregards talent and craft, just because it is popular.

Then there is the matter of the film's ending. There were three possible points where Iñárritu could have broke off the story. The first point would have been a daring and dramatic finish, an abrupt, thought-provoking conclusion I could definitely get behind. But the film continues on. The second ending would have been ... happier. Twisted, but still on the positive side. But yet again, the movie drags on. Instead of ending the film on one of two separate but acceptable points, the movie goes for an oh so masterful ambiguous ending. Of course, it's classic Birdman horse crap. One last shot at the half-baked symbolism that has pervaded the film.

The movie's musical score is another prominent example of the failure of Birdman. The original score, composed by jazz musician Antonio Sánchez, consists almost entirely of drums. Drumming, drumming, drumming, on and on for two hours. It's a bold idea, but in typical Birdman style, senseless and detracting. There were multiple times over the course of the film where the music noticeably makes the experience worse. Scenes of important dialogue and character introspection are ruined by aggressively intrusive crashing and pounding. Classical music is occasionally used, to much better ends than the drum score. Rachmaninoff's Symphony No. 2 is easily the stand-out musical cue.

Birdman is, without question, the biggest disappointment of 2014. Underneath all of its crashing, screaming, and condescending, there isn't a beating heart. The film's antiquated, "get off my lawn" mentality towards modern media wears thin after, oh about thirty seconds. It's easy to get twitterpated by the admirable camera work, but to focus on that is a disservice to the film's thematic ambitions. Yes, the movie deserves to be examined, if only to hinder bandwagon hoppers from exalting a film that so acerbically belittles absolutely everything that is "mainstream." Much like Riggan Thompson, Birdman is painfully unfunny, loud, and angry, desperately flailing about for some semblance of significance. And then it shoots itself in the head, and we have to pretend to care.

Birdman: A Smart Movie with a Stupid Ending

There is a movie making the rounds of the award shows about an actor who was last widely known for playing a famous superhero in tights. He is attempting a comeback doing something artsy, not unlike Michael Keaton in Birdman. Because it's self-reflexive, it must be FABULOUS! Well, not so much. But it is usually smart and oft entertaining. Like a piece of lesser-known theater, it has its moments. 

There are some things that are fabulous in Birdman. First, the bits of magical realism throughout the film work quite well, until the ending. Second, there is Ed Norton chewing up the scenery with controlled, skillful over-acting. And last on the list of the fabulous is the jazz drumming that follows the actors as they wind their way through the maze of rooms: dressing, make-up, costumes, and through the stage rigging, the lights and other tools of the trade found backstage at a Broadway theater. 

The other acting is as good as its script allows. Emma Stone is fun as Sam, Riggan's (Birdman) daughter, but her petulance becomes irksome after awhile. We fail to see one moment of genuine emotion from the character, even when showing her concern for her father. Her father, Riggan, is played adequately by Michael Keaton, but the famous actor down-on-his-luck schtick is tiresome. Riggan takes himself so seriously that he is a bore. Somehow, I believe that was NOT the intent of the director/writer Iñárritu. 

Naomi Watts is adequate, but her character's lines about trying to "make it on Broadway" were repeated too many times for me to care. It wasn't so much her acting that annoyed me, her hackneyed and out of place dialogue. If she improvised them, well, then it was her acting. 

Zach Galifianakis was surprisingly not the most annoying one in the movie this time. He plays the straight man, the producer of the play, to counterbalance all the lunacy of the actors. He keeps it together and does a fine job. 

Iñárritu is making an artistic comeback himself as the writer and director of "Birdman", not receiving this much acclaim since his first feature, "Amores Perros", a much more compelling drama. "Birdman" is interesting and clever with all its metaphor and fantasy. The problem is that Iñárritu could not get away from magical realism long enough to make a coherent ending. And as we all know, a terrible ending can turn a good film into a mediocre film. That, unfortunately, is what happens to "Birdman." It's treatment is so unusual, but its theme of a washout actor making a comeback so worn out, that a cogent ending was needed to make it work.  

The camera work and editing are excellent, as are the sets.  The script is at times brilliant and at other moments, mundane. Another run-through by actors and other writers may have brought some needed realism to the magic on the screen. As far as New York goes, the city plays its part well, as always. 

Rating: Matinee

It's fair, but for a better, harder hitting film featuring a washed-out actor, rent "Sunset Boulevard."
