Michael Keaton, as Birdman,  is brilliant in this movie.   Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu takes a big risk to be different in a super hero movie, and it pays off. When you think the movie is getting predictable, it changes gears in his constant struggle to put on a great Broadway play, and balance with his family.

One of the best movies I've seen in years. Birdman is a modern fable of the Icarus story mixing with the style of Hitchcock but in a scenario of Singing in the Rain. Riggan is an actor who still believed that he was "relevant" to the public but  he has become forgotten by nearly everyone about his old superhero movies in the 70s. He decided to adapt a play about love with the help from his estranged drug addict daughter. But as the days pass, his chance to become popular again became slimmer and slimmer, he must start to reconsider his stance and experience and deal with the chaotic actors and crews.

The film heavily used drum music, particularly the ambient, jazz era variety. Music was really important as the film was set in New York where the American exceptionalism was prevalent like in the Great Gatsby. Other music were also used to express the mood of the atmosphere, masterfully. Diegetic sounds were used cleverly too to create the illusion of being physically involved in the film.

The script was superb, dark yet brutally hilarious. It involved all sorts of comedies available: blue, black, slapstick, shock, embarrassing, bizarre, etc. All the characters had distinctive characteristics making them memorable and well developed. The film was about the culture of fame seeking but also satirized the superhero genre (A genre that is getting out of hand with mediocre writing, pretty faces and lots of CGI and action, e.g. Iron Man). Riggan represented Icarus (Birdman) who flew too close to the sun but began to crash and burn due to the wings catching fire from the intense sunlight. Schizophrenia was also heavily suggested, reality became distorted as his worldview crumbled.

I absolutely love the non stop tracking shots, which was used similarly to Rope by Hitchcock. The minimalism also took influence from the master of suspense. The film was unique in it's ability to confuse the audience, e.g. the camera suddenly stopped moving (audience could hear what going on in the next room) but then everything made sense as Riggan returns. 

Birdman is not merely a film, it's a piece of sophisticated philosophical art.

"Birdman" is probably one of the most hyped of movies of this awards season, however, the only word I can find to describe the film is overrated. "Birdman" follows washed-up actor, Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton) of former superhero glory, as he stars in a risky Broadway play in an attempt to revive his flat lined career. As opening night approaches, Riggan faces a crisis when one of his castmates is injured, forcing Riggan to hire an unpredictable, yet talented actor (Edward Norton) who causes problems for Riggan. Meanwhile, Riggan has to deal with his druggie daughter, Sam (Emma Stone), his ex-wife, and his inner demons that constantly torment him. Although the acting from the cast is superb, (especially from Keaton and Stone), "Birdman" is cheapened by the portrayal of Riggan's inner struggle, which is presented onscreen as a massive Birdman who torments Riggan in an overdramatic, almost laughable, Batman-esque voice throughout the film. In addition, Riggan's unstable mental state is expressed in the form of telekinesis powers and an ability to fly, which made me take the film a whole lot less seriously. However, I must admit that the directing side of the film was extremely impressive. The whole movie is filmed to appear as one long shot, with no cuts, resulting in a seamless, unique, and satirical look at society's obsession with celebrity culture and staying relevant.

I didn't know what to expect from Birdman, but what I found was a engrossing story filled with narcissistic, damaged characters played by a commendable cast.  Of course, the director deserves a lot of praise.  On a technical level, besides getting great performances from the actors in a long scene without any cuts, stitching everything together to make the film seem like one continuous take is quite an achievement.  It gives the film an artsy, Broadway play feeling that can be a little off-putting to viewers who are averse to non-Hollywood style films, but the story and performances are memorable regardless.

Firstly, I have to say it was refreshing to finally see a movie fully deserving of all the accolades and awards it's being nominated for and winning... After seeing the horrible and over-hyperd Boyhood and the lackluster Gone Girl, this was a much needed glimmer of hope.
 
This film grabbed my attention from the get-go. It was a mish mosh of arthouse, big-budget, independent but with a theatre feel to it. I was about 5 mins in before I had to ask myself, 'Is this all one shot?!"  The film flowed scene to scene effortlessly, giving the feeling of one continuous shot, a remarkable feat by director, cinematograher and editor (all deserving of awards). It gave a sort of theatre atmosphere to the film that brought you into their world and made you feel like a fly on the wall, observing but not intruding.
 
The dialogue was well-written and the acting performances all around were top notch. Michael Keaton is phenomenal, as he portrays an actor in the twilight and dwindling years of his career, trying to stay relevant and risking everything to do so. His alter-ego subconcious plays a significant role in his psyche that appears to affect the world around him. It gives us a glimpse into his world and allows us to better understand the character.
 
You can easily tell that a lot of planning, consideration, care and thought went into making this film. It's not a gimmick, but an amazing accomplishment by everyone involved in the making of.  It's not a movie that needs to be explained or defended, it stands on it's own, delivers a clear message, but still leaves a little personal interpretation for the audience.
 
For those of us who grew up with Keaton films, there's the added nostalgia and links to his film past as the Batman and his alter-ego (Birdman) almost as a Beetlejuice feel to it. I can't say enough good things about his performance, watching him reminded me of what real acting should be and I have no doubt that his co-actors raised their game to this new standard. 
 
The arthouse-like score blended the film together from beginning to end, giving a more anxious feeling and sense of urgency, appropriate to the scenes and story. There were few slow spots in the film, but were necessary for the audience to relax before bringing us back into the moment. The SFX were very well done and again, major kudos have to be given considering this appeared to be a single shot throughout (I'm still blown-away by it).
 
NYC was the perfect backdrop; the landscape and sounds virtually took me there and for 2 hours I forgot I wasn't.
 
This is a must-see film for anyone (except those who only like $200 million Michael Bay action/explosion-porn movies). Easily in my top 5 of all time
If it hadn't been for a few moments of brilliant acting this movie would have been a COMPLETE BUST!

It is not a usual drama full of dialogue or a superhero film, but the way that the screenwriters manipulate to present the whole story is surprisingly stunning. It ventures into the stage performance, film industry, the fight between the integrity and mind of the artists, the critics, the over bloating superheroes film in Hollywood; all are perfectly crafted into the life of an old actor who is struggling with his egoism in attempting to recover both his career and family. This journey of crisis, transformation, battling of stressful emotions and the inner powerful demon of himself are well played by Michael Keaton, thanks to the strong and loud jazz drum scores as well as magical, thrilling, ambitious style of delivering by Mexican director Alejandro González Iñárritu. The mind blowing and overwhelming development might make the audiences to feel that this film about art and life is imitating Nolan's style of cinematography, but the ambiguous ending has rather more complex which gives the opportunity to the audiences to decide whether to end it positively or negatively.

"I thought I knew what this movie was about. I was wrong" A man in the row behind me said these words during the first scene of Birdman. That made two of us. I thought Birdman was about a washed up superhero movie star trying to revive his career on stage. And at least on the surface it is. But that barely scratches the surface. Birdman is one of the most complex and multilayered films I've ever seen. There are deep glimpses inside the human mind, reflections on the nature of entertainment and art, scenes straight out of Terry Gilliam's Brazil or Walter Mitty, and all of it is hilariously funny and completely insane.

Now most movie reviews start by telling you what the movie is about, but I'm afraid I can't do that. I can't tell you what this movie is about, because it is about so many things at once and because words simply cannot do this movie justice. You absolutely have to see this movie for yourself. I mean that. Whatever you're doing, get up and buy tickets to this movie right now! Sorry, I didn't mean to be pushy, it's just that I just finished watching this movie and it's really got me worked up. It's that good.

Alright, that last paragraph was a little crazy. But I meant for it to be, because that will help prepare you for how crazy Birdman is, because it is utterly insane. The people in this movie are crazy. They say whatever they think, which frequently includes thoughts that would never go through a normal person head.  They do whatever they feel like, no matter how inappropriate. Ed Norton's character is especially shameless on this count. He will hit on any woman, anywhere, anytime. If something bothers him, he will act out in the most outrageous ways, no matter how many people are watching. He is the ultimate Broadway prima-donna, with no self control, unlimited ego, and the unshakeable conviction that he knows true art. In short an unbalanced A-hole who happens to act brilliantly.

When it comes to crazy though, he's got nothing on Riggan, the former Hollywood action star turned Broadway hopeful. Riggan is on the verge of a complete nervous breakdown. And much like Bruce Wayne, he has the voice of his costumed alter ego stuck in his head, reminding him of what they had together and mocking what he's become. And he may also have telekinetic powers. The movie isn't entirely clear on that point.
	
So this is a very unconventional role to say the least, and Michael Keaton is brilliant in it. He perfectly embodies every facet of the role: the endearing insanity, the anger and frustration, the ego and arrogance, the fear of being an old, washed up has-been. He does things in this movie that few actors of his stature would agree to do. He puts everything he has into this role, and a big part of it is that in a way he's playing himself. This is the guy who did the first two Batman movies after all. And come to think of it, the same is true of Ed Norton. His temperamental prima-donna is the embodiment of every story floating around Hollywood about how hard to work with.
	
Add Zach Galifianakis as Riggan's frazzled lawyer Jake and the charming Emma Watson as his longsuffering daughter Sam, and the casting in this movie is perfect. So are the writing, direction, editing, and everything else about it. The screenplay blends the real and the fantastic until you can no longer tell them apart. The pacing is flawless, alternating between the serious and the outrageous so that neither becomes overwhelming. The dialog in this movie is more offbeat and maybe more realistic than Tarantino's. And the camera hovers beside the actors, matching their pace and looking over their shoulders so that you almost feel you're standing in the room with them. 
	
And oh how this movie can deconstruct. It thoroughly dismantles the realities of acting; the jealously, egos, and clashing personalities, the overlapping worlds of stage vs. screen acting, and the very act of pretending to be someone you're not. It shrewdly examines the jaded and cynical critics, the entertainment driven news cycle, the public's current obsession with the superhero genre, and our addiction to smart-phones, YouTube, and all things viral, and what it might mean for older forms of media. In a movie where a guy in a latex bird suit follows the star around there's even time to ponder the true meaning of art. This film deconstructs all of show biz in greater detail than Unforgiven did the old west.
	
Alejandro González Iñárritu simply cannot get enough praise for what he has produced. Birdman is deep, outrageously funny, utterly insane, sometimes downright poignant, and awesome in every way imaginable. I would consider it the best movie of 2014. Like I said earlier, go see it.

Je passe sur les relations cinema/theatre, celebrite/critique, parent/enfant, mais vous aurez compris que le film est riche, malgre des messages assez simples.

Birdman (or the Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) is a movie that
represents the true power of cinema and truly shows that in this era we
live in, film is alive and well. This masterpiece really did do the job
you want from film and the story and acting and cinematography among
other things, are just perfection and it has been a long time since a
black comedy has really come close to absolute flawlessness.

One major point about this movie is Michael Keaton as Riggan Thomson
(and Birdman) and his performance here really typifies what acting can
do to us the viewer as we feel not only his emotions but also the true
power great acting is. The cast is to be fair absolute excellence
alongside Keaton and people like Edward Norton, Emma Stone and Naomi
Watts create such a display I felt this movie is one to watch for
aspiring actors because they create emotion and depth in the they're
portrayals. 

I felt the comedy side flowed beautifully as well and although coming
into the cinema screen I did feel almost like this would be overrated
in terms of laughter, I was sorely mistaken. The word black comedy is
thrown as a label on many movies these days but this is what I call
true black comedy and even the appearance of Zach Galifianakis as
Riggan's lawyer Jake just adds to the overall humour we see and manages
to be a rare film in which funny parts are mixed with dramatic
brilliance.

What else can be said about Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu other than this
man creates a movie which far surpasses anything I thought this would
be like. He masterfully directs and at times it seems so simple yet not
thought of and Inarritu locates what inside we really want from a movie
like this. He alongside others write a script that is pure gold in the
eyes of not only actors and directors but also for critics and it feels
almost impossible to criticise this movie, even with a slightly slow
beginning. 

The cinematography just adds to everything I have said and complimented
and although it may seem a stupid arsty move with the continuous shot,
It just lets you delve in to the action and really not only makes you
feel your there, but it also brings a certain reality to fictional
characters who by the end you actually start to care and feel about.
Emmanuel Lubezski at the time of writing this review is at the top of
his game still and whatever he does in the future, it can be assured
with movies like this that he will always have a part in academy award
winning film.

Don't go into this thinking "Oh it is looks too dull" or as if only
critics like this type of movie because this movie is a force and the
powerful performances can just light a spark in your eyes and it bursts
into life. I think for many this truly raises questions about the
quality of movies especially in Hollywood and how something like this
can just point out where in the last maybe decade, CGI and big budgets
have over taken true cinema storytelling made by people who seem to
care.

I think with my grade of 10/10 it means I just felt this was perfection,
and if this was truly a piece of school or university work then I would
have no choice but to declare this astounding. Although my review seems
kind of a bit crazy and over the top, the movie will make you feel
alive again in my opinion and people like Keaton who is so underrated
in the world of Filmography stick in your mind and the formula of this
is just comedy and drama and fine acting boiled up into a fine fine
movie that in truth should be classed as an epic for future generations
as we maybe see such films as On the Waterfront or Citizen Kane today.

Awesome! Great script, cast & cinematography.

Innovative & hilarious film thanks to a cast giving performances of their careers while Inarritu direction is a technical marvel.  Keaton leads a brilliant cast, giving a brilliant, semi-biographical performance as a man in the middle of a mid-life crisis while trying to find out what makes him happy.  The rest of the cast is excellent, each giving career best work (Norton shines a pretentious theater actor with more layers to him while Stone shows the biting intelligence & humor that made a star in the first place).  Inarritu direction is genius, and the 'single-take' look is not a gimmick but a device showing the hectic events of the story.  A slight quibble is the more metaphysical moments of the story stick out (is this guy Birdman for real?) but provides for plenty of thought afterwards.  Overall, one of the best & most innovative movies of 2014 and you can see why it's cleaning up during awards season.
Best film of 2014.  Alejandro's direction and the performances of Keaton and Norton are a triumph of layered brilliance.

There is so much to marvel at in this breathtakingly odd movie. If there has to be something ranked one, it should be the videography and editing. The long take that breaks only near the end is not simply well executed director's whim but a real driver of the story. The stitching of the frames and the corridor walks add to the mystery and comedy.All three leads' actings come close second. And then there are sharp dialogues, the backdrop, background score etc.

Great acting, interesting story, strong drama, funny moments and masterfully executed cinematography gives Birdman the critical acclaim it deserves.

Another one for the 'must watch again but with a notebook' files. This reminded me a lot of watching and playing jazz music (a feeling probably made intentional by the amazing and constant jazz infused drums that make up the soundtrack). Everything looks improvised but it's not really. Everything here is purposeful and I am in no position to say much after only one viewing but I'm going to try.

Everyone does a stellar acting job and I love the writing,  the soundtrack, and the way it was shot. No breaks until the end and you feel cramped and trapped in this reality the same way Reegan is. He's seeking happiness but as his ex wife says, he thinks happiness is admiration and he can't get that. He's a blockbuster actor (washed up but still) playing in Broadway's world and he is not at home or welcome here. Edward Norton's character makes that wonderfully clear as does the critic. 

The theme there between hollywood and Broadway is also done to great effect as well. The big scene with Birdman suggesting a new film is fantastic and the ending is delightfully absurd but oh so true.  The actual ending also a bit of a head scratcher but I have my own ideas and I'll keep them to myself for the sake spoilers but there are theories.

The use of "what we talk about when we talk about love" is also really interesting and it worth a separate entry.

It reminded me a lot of Black Swan and Taxi Driver in many ways and if anyone wants to chat i am more than game. I really want to see this again. 

It was really well done and really interesting. Everything thing is really tight and really intentional and i'm looking forward to puzzling over it.

Odd. Captivating. Disorienting.
All in all, a great movie. Absolutely loved the soundtrack of just Drums. It was Super effective! 
A dark rib tickler that somehow felt tense nearly the whole movie. The angles, the edges, the drums. I felt tense the whole ride.
Yet some how it remained light hearted.
Fantastic.
The ending was all the more better. We, the audience, expected a typical dark humored ending, but somehow the movie turns it all upside down and surprises you once again.
I believe it was Kant who described humor as the "sudden transformation of a strained expectation into nothing."
This movie delivers just that.
Dark Humor at its Brightest.

Entering into Birdman without trailer previewing beforehand to muddy the waters, greatly enhanced the appeal and surprises that were to be presented throughout this film. 
I can imagine that a lot of filmgoers will have left the cinema severely disappointed with expectations of a Stan Lee offering but instead an art house drama unfolding before them. This is not an underpants over the tights affair, just underpants alone (see the film!) 
I'll not mention any spoilers but simply state that it's wonderfully shot, dramatic in its dialogue and performed with feeling and depth. A great storyline underpins the whole affair making this a well crafted film.

This is a tour de force film on so many levels. The acting is superb all around the board and the directing is just phenomenal. While a film like Boyhood is something you'll never see again, I'd argue Birdman is a similar once in a lifetime film. Gonzalez's directing is simply breathtaking, as he delivers a film that's a play within a movie within a play. That may sound complicated, and for the first twenty or so minutes of the film while you're getting your bearings it is, however, once you see how the film is broken up into these collections of long, no cut, one take shots, as the camera swoops through the backstage of a Broadway set, you find yourself in awe at the sheer brilliance of it. I would definitely recommend Birdman for anyone who truly enjoys film-acting, directing, dialogue, etcetera. Along with Boyhood and Whiplash, Birdman is one of the top films of 2014 and beyond. It's dark, entertaining, funny, and most often brilliant.
A waste of time and money.
Strange and thoroughly enjoyable. I especially liked seeing Zach Galifinakis act.

Unbelievable!  This movie was artistically phenomenal. Cinematography was amazing!  Keep an open mind when watching this extraordinary struggle that Keaton experiences on screen. Well done by all cast and crew!
One of the new greatest movie of all time. Some of the greatest cinematographic works ever created and one of the deepest stories put into film with fantastic acting to compliment it.

Riggan: I'm nothing. I'm not even here.

Birdman habla de la vida de Riggan, un actor que fue famoso por su papel de superhéroe, y busca de nuevo la fama siendo director de una obra en Broadway. Somos testigos de las dificultades que encuentra en el camino y sus propias inseguridades que lo persiguen constantemente. Birdman más allá de una película es un gran logro de producción. Toda la película simula que fue filmada en una sola toma y lograr esto requiere una sincronización perfecta. Introduce también muchos elementos que normalmente no se ven en una película de Hollywood como por ejemplo esta realidad fantástica donde es difícil de apreciar que es verdadero o no. Alejandro González Iñárritu es un director que no le teme a sus retos y todas sus películas son innovadoras en su propia manera. Birdman es definitivamente la más original de todas. En cuanto a historia, me costó conectarme. Se enfoco demasiado en las tecnicalidades que lleva montar una obra de Broadway y siento que eso le quitó un poco de peso a la emocionalidad. Michael Keaton para ser el actor principal fue una opción excelente, porque él es Riggan. Fue un actor popular en su época gracias a Batman y luego desapareció, por lo cual puede reflejar su propia experiencia en el papel. Emma Stone como la hija rebelde de Riggan me sorprendió, porque este papel es completamente distinto a todo lo que ha hecho, y sorpresivamente logró dar una actuación realista. Zach Galifianakis se lució y se aleja de su fondo comédico, Norton también se lució y demuestra porqué la longevidad de su carrera y Watts y Riseborough impecables como siempre. Birdman es un buen paso hacia lo que podría ser una reinvención a el tipo de películas que se hacen en Hollywood. Ya basta de las secuelas y de las historias que se repiten una y otra vez. Fue una agradable sorpresa cuando Birdman fue nominada en varias categorias en los Oscar y finalmente ganar como Mejor Película. Es un gran paso hacia la dirección correcta.

Comedy? Uh, naw. Though a 'couple' of humorous moments, this should not be categorized as a comedy. 
I enjoyed the film yet those within the industry will appreciate this more so than the average film goer like beltway politics or hardcore sports fans. 
Was 'wonderful' to see Keaton again and hope to more often. 
Interesting, enjoyable to watch yet again, not a comedy (to me) and more of a study into the lives of those working in the industry. 
Worth the watch surely, just have reasonable expectations.
While the casting is probably my favorite part of this movie (something I've never said before), I greatly enjoyed its artistic approach and profoundly stated message.
A very unique and well done movie. Edward Norton stole the show.

Man. I really wanted to like this movie but in the end I just didn't get it. Like, I got it, but I didn't "get it" when this movie was over I didn't sit there and think about it. I didn't sit there and want to talk about it, it was just there. I saw it, I enjoyed it, and that was that. However I can understand how this movie got so much critical acclaim. The premise is quite interesting, the musical score is riveting, the performances are fantastic, there are a few monologues in this movie that will have you going... "Holy shit that was awesome", and the directing is phanominal!!! Like seriously, this movie should win best directing at the oscars hands down. One thing that was really cool was how all the shots in this movie felt like one shot. You arn't going to know what I'm talking about until you see this movie but for the people who have already seen it, you know exactly what I'm talking about. Over all I can say bird man is a good movie with a good over all story and worthy performances, but for me personally too many things got lost in translation causing me to go "wait what?" I understand the movie trying to be artistic, but when you take these artistic liberties too far you leave some viewers confused.

Beautifully shot, lit, acted and written. One of the best movies I have seen in a long time. Edward Norton is in peak form and and you can't take your eyes off Michael Keaton. Zach Galifianakis also probably gives the best performance of his career.

Birdman (2014 Film)

By Kris Scott

Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) is a 2014 dark comedy film directed by Alejandro González Iñárritu. It stars Michael Keaton with Zach Galifianakis, Edward Norton, Andrea Riseborough, Amy Ryan, Emma Stone, and Naomi Watts.


Keaton plays a faded Hollywood actor famous for his superhero role struggling to mount a Broadway adaptation of a Raymond Carver story.

The way the film was shot it was beautiful, the execution of the camera work to make it appear like one long take was perfect and worked well despite being told by officials not to have it that way was a risk worth taking.

It's a spectacular leap of faith for Iñárritu and in the end it was a successful and ambitious technical showcase with a powerful story that takes us on a flight secured by the performances of Norton and Keaton.

Overall this beautiful and hilarious piece put together immaculatelygets a definite 5 stars result from myself. Birdman will very likely fly away with multiple Oscars!
The Unexpected Virtue Of Ignorance
Fantastic! Really well worked, with an all-star cast delivering the goods and cinematography being some of the best I have ever seen. And ultimately funny!

Terrible. Couldn't even watch the whole movie. Dysthymic and mundane. The plot and the acting failed to impress. I have no idea what all the fuss and hype is about. It was meant to be dark humour? I don't think so. I was not captivated, nor did it stretch the imagination by any means. I go to the movies to escape for a few hours, to be amazed and blown away...instead I got the opportunity to be drawn into a delusional manic depressive episode of an entitled jerk's inner schema. Not my idea of a good movie...

Bearing in mind that the year is not even a month old, I have no qualms with telling you that Birdman is guaranteed a place on my top movies of 2015.

Keaton deserves the Academy award when the Oscars come around!

If the trailer peeks your interest in any way, I can assure you, you won't be disappointed.

The writing and direction are astonishing and the myriad performances from the varied cast is exquisite.

Alejandro González Iñárritu's "Birdman" is a brutally honest and nihilistic exploration of existential crisis. The film's antihero is Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton), an aging actor struggling to stay relevant within an unforgiving industry. Riddled with self-doubt, Riggan is constantly at war with the voice inside his head (which manifests audibly as the eponymous superhero he once played). The film depicts the inherent solipsism and vanity in having self-obsessed thoughts and anxieties; but, it also deeply empathizes with the desire to leave behind a meaningful legacy. 

A technical marvel, "Birdman" is filmed as though it were one continuous shot, adding to the sense of urgency and anxiety. The performances are also top-notch. Keaton's portrayal of existential angst is often brave, raw and vulnerable. Edward Norton is sharp and charismatic as Mike Shiner, an egocentric thespian who embodies the Oscar Wilde quote: "I love acting. It is so much more real than life." Filmed with stylistic verve and panache, "Birdman" is a complex and richly layered masterwork.
Absolute Perfection.

This film is beyond description but the central theme is about desiring to be relevant and matter to the world. Its about inner demons and the grandeur of delusions. I would give it the highest rating but there are moments when it comes off pretentious and the characters fall victim to the prestige rather than striving for integrity.
with performances through the roof, exceptional camera work, and a dark humorous story, it's hard not to fall in love with.

The film is the story of washed up action film star Riggan Thomson played wonderfully by Micheal Keaton. Riggan is most notably known for his roles as Birdman, a superman type action hero from the past. Keaton and his producer  Galifianakis run a small production company that is showing their first Broadway play and start running into a gauntlet of problems. They have to replace the actor opposite of Keaton and Watts. This turns out to be Edward Norton, who plays a theater star and show maker among the New York theater scene. Keatonâ(TM)s daughter is played by Emma Stone. Stone plays a daughter out of loop with her father and his time. She delivers a awes inspiring monologue that earned her an academy award nomination.



The further Birdman progresses Riggans descends further into a madness brought on by himself and his lack of self worth. He lives in an age where he has become obsolete in a world of twitter, Facebook, and a new super hero movie coming out every other month. Birdman is a tour de force. The film is a great example of what a great film needs to do to have success and earn acclaim. Bird man is nominated for nine academy awards and won for best picture,director,screenplay, and multiple other awards. The directing of Alejandro G. IÃ±Ã¡rritu really compliments the acting of the actors and he demands their full attention and top performances.
 

The true stand outs of Birdman are Micheal Keaton and Edward Norton. Great films often have multiple great scenes. This defines great films and Birdman has multiple great scenes that one would want to revisit over and over again. I love all the scenes where Riggan is unraveling and his Birdman persona is coming full force. Also Nortonâ(TM)s opening scene with him convincing Riggan he should be the fill in is one of the finer acting jobs anyone can pull off. He comes in and out of acting and reality with ease where you have no idea if he knows the difference at times or if he is acting or just going on with life.



The score is another huge factor in Birdman pulsing and making you hyped and nervous all at the same time. The constant percussion is unnerving at times and brutally honest for how the characters seem to be feeling.

Birdman is a must watch. Birdman is a 9/10 a true cinema masterpiece with few holes. The dvd just came out so go check it out.

Riggan Thompson sits in his dressing room mediating, he hovers about three feet off the ground legs folded and hands in a praying position.  Riggan Thompson was once a great comic book turned movie hero to the film industry with a legion of fans, that was all back in the 1990's. Since leaving half way through the third and fourth films his career took a dive, these days he is a washed up almost forgotten actor so to make his way back to the hearts of his fans and create some new ones he decides he will write, direct and star in an adaption of a Raymond Carver story "What We Talk About When We Talk About Love".  The play is set to debut in the St James Theatre in New York, 24 hours before the first preview screening one the main actors is injured and can't do the play.  He brings in a very well-known method actor Mike Shiner who has done more than enough to empress Riggan.   During his first preview screening Shiner does the unthinkable and Riggan's world suddenly comes crashing down around him, his estranged relationship with his daughter gets father apart, his best friend turns on him and to top it all off a famous and reviewer has threatened to destroy the play no matter how good it actually is.  With Riggan's "birdman" attacking him from the inside slowly Riggan's world becomes more than he can handle but what and how will he make this all work....

The first and last thing you will notice about this film is that of the amazing camera work, the entire film appears to be shot in one single take which is absolutely stunning to behold, fantastic idea by both the director  Alejandro González Iñárritu (21 Grams, Babel) and his lead cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki, the second thing you will notice is the brilliant acting by Michael Keaton (Batman, Beetlejuice) who plays Riggan Thompson, he is amazing in his role very believable you almost think that perhaps he isn't at all acting but being himself which must be the sign of a true genius, add to the amazing acting the stunning performance by Edward Norton (American History X, Fight Club) who plays Mike Shinner, I loved his character and thought he really helped the film where it would have otherwise fallen down.   I found the story though very lack luster, almost boring, I personally believe it just tried too hard to be an arthouse but failed, sure it had its moments and the camera work is more than enough to class this film as amazing, as is the acting from Michael Keaton and Edward Norton, I felt it needed a lot more though to deserve all the acclaim it's so far received.  Also in the cast is Zach Galifianakis as Jake, Emma Stone as Sam and Naomi Watts as Leslie.

Birdman is a film that needs your full undivided attention, I personally don't believe it will be for everyone, it is a very intellectual film (perhaps that's why I didn't enjoy it as much as everyone else) It's a film that will take you deep inside a man's mind and what makes him tick, it's a film that will wish for that little bit more and lastly I believe it's a film that lies to you especially if you have seen the trailer so don't expect no big budget action film as the trailer leads you to believe.

Review: So Birdman is the BEST movie of the year and here's why.. great performances from ALL the cast and BRILLIANT cinematography and more that I am about to get into. This film beats every film whe cinematography is involved it is made like the whole thing is filmed in 1 shot. THE CAMERA NEVER TAKES A BREAK! I couldn't find any editing even though there was editing. Just beautiful to look at. This was by FAR Michael Keatons BEST  performance! The other cast was really great as well. I thought the score was quirky and fun. The screenplay my word the screenplay. The creativeness of Alejandro Innaritu just shined in this story of a washed up movie star who used to play the role of a popular birdlike superhero named Birdman getting his life back together while writing, staring, and directing his own broadway play. He has Birdmans voice stuck in his head telling him to go back to his original role as Birdman so he can be popular cause that's all he wants is popularity and through that the character chemistry with Michael Keaton is fantastically done to where through his fights with Birdman he becomes a better person. It's hard to explain unless you see it. Overall though one of the greatest films of this decade. A perfect film with no negatives WHAT SO EVER!  It has my vote at the awards. I highly recommend Birdman if you haven't seen it see it now,  no I mean now! Best film of the year so this beats the mark and goes higher than a 10.

A manic, exhilarating thriller, Birdman is an audacious and stunning work of art from Alejandro G Inarritu, and features such a strong cast that a case could be made for up to a half dozen acting Oscar nominations. But it is the work of Michael Keaton and Emma Stone that really make viewers take notice, and make Birdman worth every second of your time.

Birdman by Alejandro G. Inarritu, is a stunning masterpiece about the downfall of Riggan (Birdman). The direction is beautiful, the writing is hilarious and dramatic at the same time, and the cinematography is breathtakingly astonishing because of the whole movie being on-shot.
The music is just drums with a few instances of real music, this works in keeping the suspense of confrontation and intensity of the characters. 
The acting by Emma Stone is quite believable and touching. But, in particular, Michael Keaton as Riggan is truly the winning best actor performance of the year. Even though Keaton was amazing, Edward Norton undeniably steals the show with his natural, funny and true character performance.
This movie will never get you lost or bored, it will just pull you into the story.

Has been actor most famous from a superhero character Birdman sets up a theatre play in NY to make a come back and show the world his artistic skills. Using (fake) single take for the entire film gives it a visual style suited for a movie about theatre and gives the cast the stage to really show their skills in long takes and dialogue heave character moments. Keaton leads the excellent cast strongly followed by Norton and Stone making both dramatic and comedic moments work perfectly. Iñárritu again proves his a true talent also in this kind of enviroment. Definitely worth checking out.

If there were an Oscar for "ensemble cast", this'd take the trophy home easily, no question. Michael Keaton is amazing as a warped version of himself struggling for appreciation and relevance, whilst Ed Norton plays his part as an up-himself-but-talented douchebag so perfectly that I'm still not so sure whether to love or hate his character. Just brilliant! The shooting style of "Birdman" makes the film seem like one long and continuous take, which becomes appropriate as you're there through every grueling moment that these characters endure, never quite getting a break from all the drama going on around them. Additionally, the constant use of closeup shots on each character really draw you into their every emotion (literally, delivering an "in your face" performance for each part). Technically, this is quite an outstanding movie, however I feel as though the storytelling -  as well as the story itself - may polarize folks who go into this not expecting a layered, philosophical journey... but at least there's some humor to go along with it.

This heavy-going and rarely funny comedy may easily slip through and win the Oscar, being the ultimate in Hollywood indulgence.  Setting itself up as a masterwork of acting, it is unrelentingly self important. On the plus side, it supports the renewal of competent artistic careers; and it gives some idea of an actor's challenges, though the latter is diminished by the sacrifice of reality in the interest of hyperbole. The film's strength is the cast, with the extended takes showcasing talent that we are rarely given to see fully in Hollywood films. The women uplift the film.  Their beauty is spectacular; they speak the truths of the story and each creates a grounded centre of her own, rescuing the film from total posturing. The male roles are more like strutting birds displaying. Keaton blasts through the film in an exhausting panoply of his own tours de force. Mostly these are photographed in tiresome closeup. In a major but typical fail, the screenplay delves into the supernatural. You groan at the beginning and can only hope against hope that it is all in Riggan's head, enough to see you through most of the film. Written as it seems by a committee, the film pecks at everything. A bizarre, eclectic superstructure balances on the one repetitive note of Riggan's career obsession. There are numerous reminders and parodies of other shows - often ironical, but derivative and childish. No doubt it is full of in-jokes and in-innuendo. As for the clunky combination of Hollywood and Broadway, there are reasons why screen acting and theatre acting are different. What it must be to live with your emotions always hurtling ahead, laying waste to everything in their path. Anyone who has undertaken a difficult role in a fragile theatre piece, that was important to them, will feel the anxieties acutely. But it is also true that theatre requires stamina, stoicism, patience and measure.  As indeed does feature film. There is no deus ex machina for actors. The film does not teach much, despite the claims that it is a look behind the scenes. It leaves that reality out of your grasp. If that elusiveness is intended as its subliminal message, it seems untrue, and too easy by far. The ending is lazy. Having clothed itself in some authority, this film misuses it.

It's funny that the two best examples I can think of for cinematography came from the same cinematographer. These two examples of course being Gravity and Birdman, filmed by the genius Lubezki. Almost seemingly shot all in one go, with the beginning and end as exceptions, simply the artistic feat of the film earns it a place in a film to be looked at for years to come, just like Gravity.

But let's look at the other aspects that make Birdman one of the best films of the year. All the supporting performances are excellent, especially Norton's, but what surprised me most was the incredible performance by the former Batman superstar. He's certainly grown as an actor, and carries this film by his shoulders. 

The story may be a bit uneven, with a few scenes that last a bit too long, and some confusing time jumps, but it really goes out of its way to be unique - to simply be an important addition to cinema. If only every film tried to be unique and set itself apart, the industry would be a much better place.

Alejandro González Iñárritu, of course, has to take almost all the credit to assemble such a fascinating study of fame and its psychological tolls on those who aim to achieve it. Great film, highly recommended, and I'll just mention the cinematography one more time.

Once a year, there comes a film that stands out among the heat of competition.  A film that stands prominent over others during awards season.  A film that makes up for Nicholas Cage flops and box office bombs or even the occasional Wayan brother film.  With 2014, Birdman is that film.  Eminently watchable, thoroughly absorbing, acted on a touching, intuitively humane level, and led with such a distinctive direction that it's near impossible to turn away from, Birdman soars over the viewers who dare miss a minute of the on-screen vibrance and promises to fascinate the rest.  It's hard to argue whether it is the best movie of the year, but I was so taken aback by its visual style and constant flow and focus that I can't say I noticed any flaws with it whatsoever, working the audience in favor of the film for both fans of live and cinematic theater.  Birdman is its own entity of magnificence that has restored my faith in film after an arguably dry and stagnant year in film and strives for and achieves on every level.  Driven by a message that can be respected by all purveyors of film in cheering on the underdog, Birdman is the underdog with the effort and appeal to remind us why film and theater is so vital, but most importantly, why small-time, arthouse productions must also be given a chance.  Thankfully, the Academy has seen to that.

Repetition is the state of film we currently have adapted to. We have all become accustomed to the fact that we watch practically the same film over and over. Yes, it may be entertaining, but it's also mind numbingly dull. 

However, in a world full of nonstop superhero blockbusters, when originality finally hits our screens, it's magical.

Birdman is the life of Riggan Thomson, an actor who played a popular Hollywood superhero over twenty years ago. Now forgotten and irrelevant, Riggan is trying to reignite his career by directing, writing and starring in his own play based on a short story by Raymond Carver. But from the previews to opening night, Riggan's psyche is split between letting the show go on, or letting the bird out of the cage. 

Birdman is completely original. You will not have ever see anything like this before. The reason being is the entire film is shown as a single rolling shot, and no cuts. A complete illusion which completely captivates the notion of a Broadway stage show under pressure, following every step of ticking time bomb  From a technological stand point of films, this is mightily impressive.

Keaton and Nortan play the best performances of their careers by far. Particularly a scene where their two characters are practising a scene for the play. The bouncing of spontaneous ideas and raw emotion between the two discussing how to perfect a conversation is incredible.

Birdman is everything I expected it to be; masterful, relevant, unexpected, compelling. An experience I will not be forgetting for quite some time.
Great film. Definitely a resurgence for Keaton. Deserving of the accolades.

Birdman is a sensational technical and psychological showcase. Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu conducts his sweeping seamless takes around the tight and closed theatre environment and ensures nothing is spared when it comes to the cast's physicality in their performances. Michael Keaton makes a miraculous return to form of a man struggling to fit into society, and in an age which is full of superhero films dominating the worldwide box office, it's a film which poses many relevant questions and ideas about celebrity identity. The entire cast are terrific, with Emma Stone particularly proving that she is not afraid of a camera right in her face when giving an incredibly emotional and physical speech. The dry drum solo score feels rather perfect for a film which is opting for a huge amount of substance as well as cinematographic style.

A genuinely funny, entertaining and clever film with great cinematography, great performances, a score as quirky and full of personality as the rest of the film, and an ending that's definitely worth talking about, as is the whole film really.

Man this movie was weird, ridiculous, raw, psychological, metaphorical and actually pretty good. I have to say even though it was chaotic at times and very strange it had a certain flow to it that ended up making sense. Michael Keaton delivers a great performance both dramatic and comedic. He plays a movie actor that was made big by playing a comic book character decades ago named Birdman. He now is trying to become relevant again after many years through doing a stage play from an old book. He encounters life problems, doubts, pressures and competition that makes you wonder if he what he is doing is actually worth it. Edward Norton does also a perfect job of playing a character that gave strife, discomfort and just plain foolishness to his co-stars because of the character's own crazy methods to his acting. An eccentric, eclectic piece of work that you would either like or dislike. I'm glad I got the chance to watch it because I actually did like it. It is vulgar and again weird at times but the story does come together at the end. Bravo to Michael and the director for doing such a risky project.

Birdman is extremely difficult to categorise because it is like no other movie you have ever seen or, probably, will ever see. Labeling it as a dramatic psychological comic tragedy would  barely skim the surface of this multi-layered tour de force which features scintillating performances from Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, Naomi Watts and, perhaps best of all, Emma Stone, who almost steals the picture in my opinion. It is not an easy film to watch with a staccato soundtrack played out by a frenetic drummer, a permanently moving hand-held camera and numerous dreamlike sequences which may or may not be actually happening. 'Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)' sets out to tell the story of Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton), an aging Hollywood movie star whose fear of becoming irrelevant brings him to Broadway in hopes of reinventing himself as a serious thespian and, naturally, quirk and chaos ensue along the way. 

For Riggan, the production-an adaptation of Raymond Carver's 'What We Talk About When We Talk About Love,'- is one mishap after the next. His co-star, Mike Shiner (Edward Norton) is a pain to work worth, his fresh-out-of-rehab daughter (Emma Stone) constantly reminds him that he's both a washed up actor and a lousy father, and a surly New York Times theater critic decides to hate the play before even seeing it. Then there's Birdman-a superhero Riggan played in the blockbuster franchise that launched his career-who haunts him day in and day out. This ghost of Hollywood past fuels the actor's self-doubt and self loathing, blurs his sense of reality, and eventually, leads Riggan to a full-blown descent into madness. 

But instead, 'Birdman' does a better job at telling the story of an aging movie director, whose fear of irrelevance leads to his own attempt at reinvention through a stab at satire and-because the filmmaker clearly fears failure as much as does irrelevance-clutter, banality and desperation plague, what otherwise, could have been one hell of a movie. 

'Birdman' had so much potential. Its stellar cast, featuring Michael Keaton, Edward Norton and Zach Galifianakis, among others, collectively delivers solid performances across the board. The cinematography is not only beautiful, but also serves to give the film an uncannily distinct aesthetic from beginning to end-an aesthetic that is further accentuated by an atmospheric musical score, which, consisting predominantly of jazz drum rhythms, captures both the film's midtown Manhattan setting as well as the escalating neurosis of its protagonist. 

However, in all other respects, 'Birdman' fails to deliver. The movie's most glaring flaw is its complete lack of focus-it simply tries to be too many things at once. 

Thematically, it appears to aim for dark satire. The cinematography, for instance, which has been praised for giving 'Birdman' the look of one continuous shot the whole way through, is actually remarkable for a different reason-which is that the use of lighting and camera angles makes every scene and every frame look like a comic strip panel, if paused and gone over in pencil. And that's damn fitting for a dark comedy/drama about a man that once played a superhero, and his weird, imaginary superhero frenemy/alter-ego! 

In their roles, Keaton and Norton both poke fun at their real life public personas-Keaton really WAS the star of a superhero film franchise back in the day, and Norton really IS known for being a masterful yet hard-to-work-with actor. It's clever because we like it when actors prove to be in on the joke. 

Should 'Birdman' have fully committed to farcical absurdity, the film would have been a live-action, existential comic book for the thinking man-successfully spoofing show business while making a statement about celebrity culture, social media, today's desensitized, bloodthirsty audiences (Riggan gets a rave review from the aforementioned bitter critic only because he shoots his own nose off onstage during his play's premier, thereby "proving" himself a true artist), and of course, the destructive capabilities of our own minds. 

But 'Birdman' did not accomplish what it had the potential to do, due to its inability to fully embrace the intended motif. The script and story line didn't allow the leads to be the caricature-esque archetypes the film needed in order to be a dark, comedic parody of actors. 

Instead, the stereotypes, particularly those portrayed by Keaton and Norton, were tainted by sporadic (and rather unnecessary) bursts of depth and idiosyncrasy. The result made for a roster of on-screen personalities which were neither one-dimensional enough for satire, yet not developed enough to make for a character driven drama. You neither fully care, nor fully not care about them-and apathy is perhaps the worst kind of emotion a film can illicit. 

The film's lack of follow-through brings me back to, what appear to be obvious parallels between its lead character and its director, Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu. Like Riggan, Inarritu, 51, perhaps decided to go against the grain of the heavy dramas that made him famous and prove to viewers that he's still got a few tricks up his sleeve, by dipping his toe into the waters of dark humor. 

But based on the end result, Inarritu wasn't comfortable enough with the genre to fully commit to it, because 'Birdman' is peppered with many of the same dramatic elements that have proven successful with audiences in the past-seemingly just to be on the safe side, but making for a muddled, wishy-washy mess of a movie instead.

Inarritu's insecurity is best exemplified by the film's antagonist-a New York Times theatre critic who hates Riggan for daring to set foot on Broadway, which she believes to be reserved for serious actors and not Hollywood sell-outs. She's heartless, callous, uncaring and straight up villainous in her determination to shut down Riggan's production via the power of a bad review. Inarritu gets an A+ for actually not overthinking her as a character, but D- for trying to conceal a built-in deterrent from any real-life bad reviews that his attempt to venture outside his comfort zone could potentially be subject to. It's a cowardly message to critics: I'm going to make you look bad, before you get a chance to make me look bad. 

And perhaps Inarritu was right to be nervous. He's got the cinematic exploration of the human condition down to a science, but when it comes pop culture and comedy, a natural he is not. 

His previous films, like Amores Perros, Babel, 21 Grams and even the uncomfortably heavy Biutiful, all feature at least a handful of funny moments-like, actually really funny moments-which work because they aren't forced. In 'Birdman' much of the humor tries too hard-and worse yet, feels like listening to your grandparents trying to sound 'edgy.' 

When Naomi Watts' character (a member of Riggan's cast whose storyline is feverishly made out to be of great importance to the film in its first 40 minutes, then inexplicably completely ignored for its remainder) cries, "Why don't I have any self-respect?" to a fellow female cast member, her friend replies,  "You're an actress, honey." Zing? Oh no, he didn't? Someone's FINALLY dared to call out actresses as being fucked up and vulnerable? The joke kind of seems like the overused, low hanging fruit one would expect from a rom com or Adam Sandler movie-not an Oscar contender. Unfortunately, the film features plenty more examples of such pedestrian humor and is only genuinely funny when Keaton, Galifianakis and Norton deliver unintentionally funny lines in a prodigiously humorous manner-which fortunately, they frequently do. 

And instead of letting the movie's plot organically serve as social commentary, that aspect is forced as well. Kids today only care about Twitter and going viral, rather than plays and stagecraft. Yes, we've known this for a while and the film's smug use of social media jargon comes off as Inarritu's way of proudly demonstrating that he knows what it is and how it works-and ironically makes the filmmaker look even more out of touch than he would have if he just didn't reference it at all. 

Actors are tortured, insecure people, incapable of healthy relationships or dealing with reality. Yep, that's also been covered before. 

And how about the tremendous opportunity the film had to address the escalating insignificance of the New York Times? Instead of lampooning the relic publication's comically out-of-touch ways, the film maintains an antiquated and, no longer existent, level of reverence of a newspaper that's long since become a joke. 

In fact, 'Birdman' manages to insult viewers' intelligence on other levels as well. Take, for instance, the epic spoiler of a line that comes damn near the beginning of the film, in which Mike Shiner (Norton) tells Riggan (Keaton) to have some respect for himself by getting a more realistic-looking gun to use in the play's final scene (in which Riggan's character commits suicide).  The scene lacks so much as even an attempt at subtly. Thirty minutes into the movie and you already know how it will end-the tortured, desperate for actor-cred Riggan is going to shoot himself onstage with a REAL gun.

 It would have worked as foreshadowing, had Riggan's attempt at onstage suicide not been the film's conclusion, but rather a pivotal moment which leads to a greater, more profound epiphany, or steered the plot in a specific direction. But no. You are literally (and shamelessly) told at the beginning of the film, exactly how the film is going to end, and are STILL expected to be surprised by its final scenes, you fucking idiot, you! 

All that said, my love and respect for Inarritu remains unwavering despite this cinematic blunder. I do respect his desire to branch out beyond, what has become, "classic Inarritu." And he did...okay, at it. As a fan, I'm not mad, I'm just disappointed. But at the same time, given his talent, sense of humor (when he's not trying too hard), amount of A list actors at his disposal, and eye for visually sexy filmmaking, Inarritu-whose 'testing the waters of satire' project wound up being a critically acclaimed Oscar contender-is poised to dominate the genre before long, should he choose to do so. Personally, I'd like to see him make a black comedy in which he redeems himself for the shortcomings of the if-it-had-been-directed-by-anyone-else-it'd-be-great 'Birdman.' Which I trust he can. But I also wouldn't be mad if he made Amores Perros 2.
Michael Keaton nailed this movie. I do not think any other actor could have carried it the way he did.

Absolutely incredible film. I haven't seen anything quite like this in my life. Genius writing and wonderful acting. Couldn't imagine anybody better for this movie than those chosen for it. Not a dull moment in this film. I have yet to have seen Michael Keaton put on a better performance than he did in this film. HIGHLY recommend. I can't think of a single bad thing about this movie except I wish the movie had been longer. I am definitely buying this movie.

I really enjoy how creative this movie is, but I don't think it deserved movie of the year. Yeah, Micheal Keaton did a great job playing a schizophrenic, but something about this film put me to sleep (got a little boring).

This really is a powerhouse of a film, certainly one of the year's best.  It follows an aging for action-movie star as he mounts his first production on Broadway.  He is trying trying to reinvent  and validate himself, while at the same time working on his personal relationships including his daughter, his girlfriend, and his ex-wife.  Keaton is absolutely outstanding, makes the character very real, and relate-able in a way.  I can't imagine Keaton not winning the Oscar.  The supporting cast is also outstanding.  The cinematography blew me away, perhaps the best of the year.  As usual, Iñárritu direction is top-notch, I always love his films.  This is a MUST watch film, so check it out!

Riggan Thompson (Michael Keaton) is an ex-Hollywood mega star who at the peak of his career played the illustrious Birdman but currently finds his career in the tank. As a last chance at rekindling his iconic days he is fully financing, acting and directing a Broadway stage production of a Raymond Carver short story. Around him, his daughter Sam (Emma Stone) is desperately trying to show him that his method behind his quest for pop culture relevancy is archaic and outdated. Thompson's business partner and agent Jake (Zach Galifianakis) tries to keep his clients ego in check and turns a blind eye to the cracks appearing in this ageing movie stars ego, an ego that lusts for revitalisation and fame. Thompson's ex wife and current lover both have active roles within the theatre he is performing act as well has his deranged acting partner Mike (Edward Norton) who has incredible acting talent but a delicate psyche. Every character has a heavy influence of Thompson's story as he struggles to succeed with his play and regain his stature in the performing arts in the face of a film critic determined to close his show as she feels he is underserving of that iconic stage.

Director Alejandro González Iñárritu's intention was to shoot Birdman as if it was just one long take, and it really feels that way as the story flows perfectly and the editing is virtually invisible. Scenes lasting several minutes - requiring the cast to learn up to 15 pages of dialogue verbatim while also hitting their physical marks and cues - meant Birdman wrapped in less than a month of shooting. It's no big secret that while Birdman is very close to home for Keaton it is also miles away, the character of 'Birdman' represents the career high for Keaton when he played Batman in 1989/92 but in this production the 'Birdman' character, to wit only Thompson can visualise, represents and manifests as his overpowering ego convinced that everybody is trying to impede and restrict him. Thompson rages an internal battle against this 'Birdman' toward a dramatic psychological crescendo that will leave you thinking. Fantastically well made, amazing camera work and indeed career best performance from Keaton. This is exactly the type of movie the Academy loves, it's high brow, it's multi layered and very cerebrial. At time of writing it has 9 2015 Academy Award nomination and I believe it's in with a good shout for either Best Actor/ Best Movie. Watch the space, but first watch this movie!

FutureProof Movie Review Score: 8.5
great film that everyone should see!! didn't like the ending at all, but the film was worth the watch

Thought this was moving, funny, weird, technically excellent and fantastically well-acted. I heard a review suggesting it was too "full of itself" but I found it to be quite simple in the story it was trying to tell.  The single tracking shot is impressive and there certainly are 'out-there' elements to it, but for me it was the warmth in the characters interactions that made this one of the best films I've seen in a long time.  Michael Keaton, Ed Norton and Emma Stone all deserve the praise that has been coming their way.
Michael Keaton is incredible, one of my favourite actors.
Cool movie, if a bit overrated. Michael Keaton is great, as is Emma Stone.
a brilliant and often exhausting film. the long takes really work well, and the acting is superb. I could have toned down the percussion drumming soundtrack, as it sis get intrusive at times.
Bizarre, but brilliantly shot, acted and full of suspense.

Great performances by Michael Keaton and Ed Norton, but this movie was mediocre at best.  From the annoying jazz drummer background throughout to the overall weirdness at every scene turn, I was not bowled over by it.  Jesus, do they make "good" movies anymore or do we just shoot for originality?
Inarritu's finest since Amores Perros.

OK, 'it's trawl though the psyche of insecure actors' ' clunkingly obvious I thought, and it's also 'not as clever as it thinks it is': frankly It gave me a headache. A few funny moments, but I was glad to get out of the cinema.

#Birdman was oddly refreshing. Interesting parallels for the real life Batman actor playing a role of an actor trying to find fulfillment in his life's work and prove excellence in his craft. A common link between each character is how they skew their reality, all about perception. Michael's perception of reality and fiction, Edward's inability to separate performance from reality, Ema's misdirected frustration with her father, Zach's constant manipulation of the truth, other charters disillusioned about relationships and self identity. Artistically filmed, as it's also directed with blurred imagery of fiction and reality (what was imagined vs real). This film also takes a stab at critics, Hollywood productions, feeble minded audiences, social media and etc. Edward brings life to the film during the slow development phases. Superb acting by all of the cast  with #MichaelKeaton #EdwardNorton #ZachGalifianakis and #EmaStone leading the way. Quite a few stand out scenes and classic quotes that resonate as truthful and real. This movie isn't for everyone's taste, mostly about the dialogue.
It has got Oscar written all over it.
Birdman provides an exceptional and seamless depiction of mental deterioration while also boasting what might have been the most well-cast film of 2014.
Pretty good movie, but not my favorite. I felt like I was watching Mr. Brooks and Black Swan at the same time.
Very disappointing. Terrible music. Michael Keaton's performance isn't that great either.

Every now and then a movie comes out that takes a different approach to the most basic elements of film. In this case the uniqueness lay in the camera format. There are no cuts, everything is shot on one continuous shot that follows the character being focused on at any given time around to create a more real time play-esque atmosphere. Upon first hearing about this, I was intrigued but doubted that over the course of an entire movie that this style would not hold up. But how wrong I was, outside of the few rare occasions when the camera would've benefitted from being a little further back, the angling and continuous drawn out shot work succeed in making Birman a refreshing, daring experience to watch unfold. 
BIRDMAN or The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance is a black comedy that tells the story of a fading actor (played beautifully by an uncharacteristically energetic Michael Keaton) famous for his portrayal of an iconic superhero- as he labours to mount a Broadway Play. The days leading up to the opening night show the actor struggling against ego, familial strain, his career and most worrisome of all, his own mind. I found it interesting that Michael Keaton chose this role as it appears to mirror his own career. He of course known to most for portraying Batman in the Tim Burton adaptations in the late 80's and early 90's, has, much like his character done nothing of much consequence in the years since. Going into this film, I was not a Keaton fan. After watching his performance though, I am now firmly on his bandwagon. In every scene Keaton displays a previously untapped energy and feverish passion that forces the viewer to sit up and look on in awe. His comic timing and body mannerisms remain on point from beginning to end and help to stop even the most casual of watchers from losing focus. However, despite his performance, Keaton does not turn in the best display of the film. That honour belongs to Edward Norton. Playing his character (that of a wildly eccentric, pretentious theatre actor) with more gusto than we've seen from him in year, Norton owns every moment of screen time that he is given. Perhaps it was good direction or perhaps it was a strong endearment for the material, but Norton has thrown himself into this role and elevates him to the positon of Oscar contention later this year.
good turns are also provided by the supporting cast Zach Galifianakis under plays slightly, while also delivering his punchlines so subtly you'd almost suspect he came up with each one on the spot. While Emma stone plays a tired and worn out trope of modern cinema, the angst wrought daughter with father issues, with enough charm that one can almost overlook the fact that you've heard it all before.
The faults of the movie are few and far between. Yet, if I had to nitpick I'd say that the apparitions of Birdman himself could use more clarification. At times you are lost as to whether or not he is real and if Keaton does possess the powers put on show in all the trailers. Another thing to strife over is the occasion social media aspect that gets shoehorned in. Such little is said in relation to the internet you're left wondering; Why bring it up at all?

Ultimately, this comes highly recommended. Blending art-house narrative with a mainstream flare perfectly I can't help but feel that this is the movie that "Synecdoche New York" had wanted to be but failed in finding the blend between reality and otherwise. Five stars.
