Truly a disappointing film with no redeeming value to entertain.  Couldn't wait for it to be over.  Hollywood's attempt to show the toil and troubles of actors for its own sake.
A ono... cudan, precudan za moj ukus
Stunning. Modern Woody Allen.

Hand Michael Keaton the Oscar now! Birdman really is unlike any film you've ever seen nor will you ever see! Michael Keaton is incredible in the role he was born to play! Supporting actors including Edward Norton, Naomi Watts, Zach Galifanakis, and Emma Stone are all nearly as impressive and the direction by Alejandro Gonzalez Inaritu is nothing short of iconic! Birdman is so crazy, weird, and incredibly original I would say it's nearly a perfect film!

Just because something is original doesn't make it good. I'm reading some critic reviews to see why it got such good ratings. All I'm seeing is that it's one of a kind, edgy, and superbly shot. I'm not seeing where people are saying it's actually a good movie. Too many times do people get too carried away by one thing like technical achievements rather than judging the film as a whole. I do have to disagree that the film is well acted. It is over acted. I found myself many times throughout the movie thinking about how evident it was that they were acting - and I'm not talking about the parts on stage. The interactions were unrealistic. This movie reminds me a lot of American Hustle in that the way people talked to each other was way over the top. It was a star-studded cast of actors over-acting. I'd also have to disagree with the entire genre of this movie. It's not a black comedy or even a drama. It's more like a fantasy, partly because of the dialogue, partly because of the content. I would also have to disagree that this is about a midlife crisis. It's more about a psychotic breakdown. I think they just got it all wrong.
Very interesting movie.
Terrible film.  The most pretentious film ive ever seen. The biggest waste of time in film history.
Quite possibly the best film I've ever seen.

A movie that is going to appeal to a narrow audience, and I'm thankful to be a part of that. A performance of a lifetime from Keaton that is kept flowing with creative and incredible cinematography and witty dialogue. Dark at times, but Norton and Galifianakas balance the plot. Well crafted satire presented in the most odd ways maintains the audience's interest from start to finish. And that nasty voice inside his head provides a clever and thought conjuring antagonist, having you question who Riggan really is. Well deserving of an unprecedented 9 Academy nominations, finally a smart, different movie breaks its way into the mainstream. 5 Stars, yes its a masterpiece.
O regresso de Iñárritu aos grandes filmes.

Inarritu's original Black Comedy is a one of a kind film going experience filmed almost as one shot. It gives Michael Keaton his role of a lifetime and he delivers with superb support from Norton, Stone, Watts, Duncan Ryan, Riceborough, and Galafanakis. One satisfying cinematic experience! 01-17-2015
Superb acting, but I dunno what to say about its general weirdness and total meandering plot. Quite confusing as a whole but great visuals and performances

"Birdman" is really odd but you have to see it.  Its cinematography, which captures the entire film as if it was a single tracking shot, is absolutely stunning and gives the film a unique feel that is unlike any other.  While some trickery is used to create this effect, it still necessitates that each scene be shot in one take as each stop and start of the camera occurs during a transition between scenes.  The tracking shots within each scene can last up to 15 minutes, requiring the actors to be on point with their timing and emotions at every moment while the crew and cameraman must operate with absolute precision.  The Oscars don't lie when it comes to the acting categories and, when a film receives nominations in three of those categories, you know that you are going to see strong emotional monologues and a lot of chemistry.  Michael Keaton, Edward Norton, and Emma Stone do not disappoint.  Keaton has spent most of his career dwelling in comedy and action roles that put him in the spotlight but never proved him as a great actor.  Everything changed with the release of "Birdman."  The role of Riggan Thomson has allowed Keaton to put on a dramatic, psychological performance in which he is unpredictable, unstable, and gets to really freak out.  Edward Norton adds to his repertoire of arrogant jerk roles with several high-energy scenes that leave you hating him (as usual).  Emma Stone, who I believe to deserve more credit as an actress than she receives, secured her Oscar nomination with a single scene in which an impassioned monologue allows her to flex her acting muscles.  The supporting cast adds to the natural feel of the film and director Alejandro González Iñárritu had incredible vision to put this entire film together within a playhouse on Broadway.  He is no stranger to the Oscars as all five of his feature films have received nominations, and this film will surely take home a few.  I do take issue with the trail of loose ends that this story does not resolve.  It is obvious that the writers want the reality of Keaton's superpowers, whether they exist or are in his head, to remain ambiguous.  This results in an incredibly clever ending that forces us to reflect on the characters and decide what happened; however, what is the purpose of including seemingly significant events and never addressing them again?  Naomi Watts and Andrea Riseborough seem to disappear from the film for no particular reason after "the scene", Amy Ryan creates insight into Keaton's character and then also disappears, but why?  I feel like this misuse of characters cheapens an otherwise inspired script.  I like this because it is something different, from its single tracking shot approach to its use of a real Broadway playhouse for its set.  It is rare that a director can create a film that defines its own style, but "Birdman" is undoubtedly one of a kind.
Excellent direction, great acting. About an hour too long with a few unnecessary plot developments that added little to nothing and went nowhere.

Mitä tästä nyt sanoisi.. huh! Tässä oli jotain uutta, raikasta ja yllättävää, hauskaakin. Aikas huikea kuvaus ja intensiivinen näyttelijöiden meininki. Monikerroksinen käsikirjoitus joka sanoo paljon teatteri/elokuvamaailmasta ja muustakin. Keaton kyllä antaa kaikkensa, repertuaari on laaja. Suosittelen.

A pretentious, disjointed, mess of a film.  Unique?  Yes, but that's not always a good thing.  Repeatedly relies on an annoying audio trick to signal the viewer that we are about to see "drama".   Some decent humor and a very attractive female cast save this film from being a total disaster.  Had the potential to be a great film in the "unrealized dreams" genre, but missed the mark IMO.  Out of 1000 points, I'd give it 220, 221.
Fantastic piece of cinema which delves deep into the psyche of a modern film star who has faded into irrelevancy.

Michael Keaton gives the performance of his career in this brilliant and original film. It's Keaton's Pulp Fiction. Not only is Keaton terrific but the supporting performances are solid - Emma Stone, Edward Norton and Zach Galafanakis are brilliant. The movie appears to be shot in one continuous take which makes it a technical masterpiece. It almost has to be seen twice to be truly appreciated.

A slightly insane, wry and often sad film, which is rather hard to categorise. Keaton is superb, his twitchy face betraying frustration, anger, fear and a degree of madness. He's supported by a cast all on form, and the only criticism is that as it focuses in on Keaton, characters and plot strands are left dangling or fade into the background.
Un-comparable! Stands alone in a tsunami of generic superhero collaboration bullsh*t! Truly good! Fresh!

Its a movie designed to get awards from fellow actors who have an inflated view of their own importance   Way over directed to the point of distraction.   Michael Keaton is a washed up actor famous for his role as a super hero playing a washed up actor famous for his role as a super hero.  Wow, what an acting stretch.

Birdman is actually pretty good! It's a very good story, with some brilliant performances. Edward Norton, as always, is beyond awesome with a oscar-worthy character. The only downside was probably the way Riggan's conflicting personality is depicted - it's a brilliant idea, but it ends up taking a hold of the plot, and turning it into a bit of a confusing mesh.

A original and breathtaking Black Comedy created by and masterfully directed by Inarritu and Starring the magnificent Michael Keaton in the role of his career as a washed up actor fighting for redemption for his sordid past. The supporting cast also shines due to the talents of Norton, Stone, Watts, Duncan, Ryan, Galafanakis, and Riseborough. It is filmed as almost one continuous shot and I was sucked from the opening on. A definite don't miss! 01-17-2015
A good play on both the history of Batman AND Keaton to create a brilliant surrealist drama. Definitely worth watching.
Keaton was phenomenal....
A stange and intriguing film carried by a brilliant performance from Keaton. Birdman dives deep into its title character with dark comedy and heart.

Washed up Hollywood star Riggan wants to prove he is a "real" actor by directing and starring a play on Broadway. But perhaps he cannot, because he is mental.

Wrapped around the claustrophobic world of actors, the movie is an exercise in navel-gazing and smugness. I guess it must be a big deal for a Hollywood superstar to prove to his peers that he is not just a money-making machine but also a talented actor.  However, I truly do not care about the hysterics and anguish of Hollywood actors.

That is why, when Birdman was acclaimed by the critics I already suspected yet another inflated balloon full of nothing.  I waited until I could watch the movie for free, because I was very reluctant to waste money on yet another "Academy-worth" piece of crap and I am very happy I saved my hard-earned money
 
The joke is twice on the audience, because the other theme explored by Birdman, besides narcissist actors, is audience stupidity. Not being the sort of person who cares about superheroes movies, I was nevertheless annoyed by the fact that the public of said movies is vilified by this piece of elitist crap. 

It is difficult to point out what I disliked most about Birdman, since I hated everything: the overbearing drum soundtrack, characters shouting their lines, the smugness of the whole concept, the patronizing dialogues, etc... I do not even think Keaton was so great in it.

Finally, it is depressing to notice that the number of movies I want to walk out from is increasing exponentially. After decades of watching movies, what I expect is an interesting story told in an engaging way, but what I find is more and more egotistic directors busy only with producing crap bearing their trademark signature, being it Tim Burton Goth-chic or Wes Anderson smug-naïve.

Strange, strange film. Norton and Keaton carry it. Decent ensemble cast, with an interesting almost microcosmic interpretation of Keaton's career. Not massively funny, but entertaining. The last 20 minutes dragged too much for a short film.

Absolutely blew me away. Best film i've seen in a while and first time writing a review on here for a film. Start to finish, very unique, terrific story, great playhouse, best city, amazing acting/actors and the single camera shot work.. just all top notch. 5 stars. 
The the directing and extra metaphorical shots added at the start and end of the film really close out the story well.
Though great performances by all the actors, the movie never takes you to a joyful place and leaves you confused and sad.

A great movie with a terrific cast! The movie has a dynamic and the story is so well delivered that we are easily drawn into it. Did not feel so much as a comedy but more as a drama with funny parts. The story is not new but it is told in a refreshing different way. Not sure if I like the last 5 min..

This was strangely wonderful and recommended.

I found this movie to be overindulgent. Actors showing off that they can act. After all it is a movie set on Broadway!!! The soundtrack was annoying. Didn't think it was as good as people are making it out to be. But still watchable!
A technical tour de force and an actor's showcase, Birdman is an odd, exhilarating and thoroughly unique film.
Clever direction and great acting make this an engaging and worthwhile watch.
Admired it more than I enjoyed it. Top rate performances. Backstage drama and hijinks abound!

'Birdman' plays out as a cautionary tale about a former superhero actor turning Broadway director encounter the many disasters and implications with the production and his reputation upon the outside world. Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu directs this film with such passion and precision its almost hard to look away from the outstanding articulated camera shots aided with powerful performances from such a talented cast its story is almost hard to comprehend. While it may feel very organic upon its layering the film is also incredibly surreal as if to portray very specific allegories from its main character(s). The film can also be viewed as a satire upon creativity and actor's careers, but its so flawless within its execution there's nothing else it could compare to let alone be bettered with. Its a one of a kind film that should be viewed from all kinds of audiences all around and just witness the severity and impact this film creates.

Taking a vicious stab at Hollywood and has-beens, this comedy sizzles with acidic self-depraciting wit. It is also an awe-inspiring cinematic ambition to shoot the whole movie in one take (or well, almost).
Slow, boring, pretentious. The worst kind of Oscar-bait there is.
Love love love love love!!
I know the critics loved this movie but I generally thought it was a bit of a hot mess.  There were parts of the movie which honestly don't make any sense at all.  Just rather strange and weak imo.
Odd, Interesting, and Unique, but in it's script and filming style. Interesting story told very well.
Rarely get a movie with this grasping power and yet be classy. And what a piece of acting
You are unlikely to see a better crazy and creative film this year. Birdman is filmed like a play but choreographed like a dance. You won't forget this one. A must see.
Good, and the acting was outstanding, but I wouldn't call it best picture.
I honestly hated it!  The dark lighting, those stupid drums, the 'this is an art film'so we will make it really weird feeling.
Odd movie.  Acting was excellent but story was all over the place.

Do not eat before this movie.  Clever director made entire movie one long continuous shot.  Felt so sick, I had to leave theater, and was hard pressed to come back in.  Was supposed to be a black comedy, but really just dark.  Some good performances, but I will more strongly recall the need to retch in the parking lot.  Save it for DVD so you pause frequently.
Incredible performances. Beautifully shot.  Gritty and intimate. Michael Keaton turns in a masterpiece. .

I can honestly say I've never seen a movie like this, cinematically.  Seemingly filmed in one take, Birdman is impressive.  Became a little too existential at the end for me, probably why it couldn't give it 5 stars (but it was darn close.) Michael Keaton has been given much props on his performance, rightfully so, he hits it out of the park as a former and very broke movie star trying to stay relevant, but I feel like he's the best player on a team of very good players... Emma Stone, Ed Norton, Zach Galifianackis, Naomi Watts all played the perfect neurotic tones.  Not quite my favorite film of 2014 but definitely deserving of all the accolades...
Every bit calculative.
Different but very interesting.
what a boring movie. waste of time and money. the story is portrayed in a really uninteresting and weird manner. didnt like it. if you have no interest in Broadway you might not like this movie.
Great performances by Michael Keaton and Edward Norton, Naomi Watts. A little overly long, disliked the ending. Worth a view.
Excellent movie. The acting as well as the cinematography was very well executed. It got me sucked in. Despite it being kind of confusing it was still very well made.

I have no idea what I just watched.   I can't tell if I hate it or not.   I think it was operating at a whole different level and I should have got something out of it that I didn't.   It felt a bit like Black Swan.   There were pieces of it that felt like Adaptation (with the plot within a plot).    Some of the technical aspects (the cinematography/editing) were really remarkable.  And some of the performances bounced between great and overacting. Going head to head with Boyhood for the Best Picture Oscar, this quirky meta-dramedy about a washed-up movie star attempting redemption on Broadway has generated much applause from critics around the world. It's not hard to see why, what with director Alejandro González Iñárritu's ambitious technical achievements, the razor sharp satirical screenplay and a bunch of soul-bearing performances. Presenting the story as one long continuous take, Iñárritu employs all the tricks of the trade in search of something unique and it largely pays off; his ever-flowing camera segues between scenes creating a dreamlike atmosphere. Finding where the shots have been joined, however, can at times distract from the emotional journey crafted by Iñárritu and his team of writers, in a script full of dark humour and irony. Unfortunately there's also a hint of pretention and self-satisfaction in Iñárritu's work - intentional and otherwise - that comes across as smug and, therefore, annoying. As Riggan Thomson, the former A-lister seeking professional rejuvenation on the stage, Michael Keaton gets a long-awaited opportunity to shine in a lead role and attacks it, for better and worse, with unbridled gusto. Ed Norton hogs the spotlight though, with a comedic turn as a supercilious stage actor looking for the "truth" in even the tiniest of things, whilst Emma Stone, Naomi Watts, Zach Galifianakis, Andrea Riseborough and Amy Ryan round out the impressive cast. Birdman is clever, enterprising and admirably distinct, if occasionally laborious and inaccessible; it's not for everyone, but lovers of film and/or theatre should seek it out.

Birdman is astounding, brave and bold film making. But when the director is the masterful Inarritu you should expect nothing less. A dazzling film on many levels this is a story about lost souls, identity, celebrity and meaning in the world. Michael Keaton is superb as Riggan Thomson, a man searching for answers many years after reaching fame as 'Birdman'. His soul searching takes him to Broadway to star in and adapt Raymond Carver. All the while his inner voice of 'Birdman' is questioning his every move. He seeks answers but can't find them. Throw in a troubled relationship with his daughter and his battles with the ego of his star actor, the great Edward Norton, and you have a potent mix of regret and ambition. This is a sad, dark and funny film. It pokes holes in the modern film world obsessed with comic book adaptations and the world at large concerned with celebrity. To add to the mastery of the film is the sublime cinematography of  Lubezki. He has combined with the director to construct the film as if it shot in one take. The effect is to thrillingly lead you on a non stop journey through the theatre, a theatre of dreams. Of fantasy. This wonderful films plays with big ideas. The fact that it totally succeeds is even more astounding.

Michael Keaton's most recent cinematic turn as Riggan Thomas in Mexican director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's Birdman is the bravest performance of the year from a leading actor, laying bare all of Keaton's insecurities, vanities, and virtues through a fictional character who possesses more than a passing resemblance to Keaton himself. Riggan is a washed up, out of work Hollywood actor, attempting to breath new life into a public image that has been distorted and manipulated by the cult of celebrity, bringing with it all of the personal vices of arrogance, avarice, and self-absorption that such distortions of self-worth and identity inevitably represent and instill. Likewise, Keaton is a figure of the popular culture who appears as more of a caricature than a three-dimensional actor in the collective mind of the general public, associated with some of the most iconic movie characters from the 1990's, including Batman and Beetlejuice, thereby mirroring Riggan's association in Inarritu's film with the fictional big budget superhero, and at times near literal alter-ego, Birdman. Inarritu's film thus becomes an examination of the blockbuster movie star, simultaneously celebrating and deriding the actor whose relevancy is at times more dependent upon the associations conjured up by the characters he portrays as opposed to the power of each individual performance, Birdman bigger than Riggan, in much the same way that Beetlejuice looms larger than Keaton, in both name and persona. Michael Keaton's cultural status as one of the big budget stars of the 1990's thus becomes a meta-fictional aspect of the very fabric of Innaritu's film, inevitably informing the audience as to how to read Riggan's deeply conflicted interiority and ego-driven flights of astrally projected fantasy, visually represented in the film through Inarritu's use of one continuous, and spectacularly edited, long shot, seamlessly encompassing the entire film, and further mirroring Riggan's subjective vision and reality in a way that is intensely characteristic of the film, the character, and the surreal nature of Inarritu's beautiful meditation on the unexpected virtue of ignorance.

The frame narrative of Inarritu's film centers around a stage production of the classic American short story collection What We Talk About When We Talk About Love by minimalist writer Raymond Carver, adapted and produced by Keaton's Riggan Thomas in the lead role, providing for an accessible point of entry into the film's visually driven first person narrative, as Riggan's highly subjective point of view very quickly begins to drive the entire course, and at times alter the reality of, the film's plot and cinematic scope. As the camera pans across and through the small, claustrophobic hallways and back stages of New York's Broadway theatre district, the playhouse a veritable Pandora's box of Riggan's artistic dreams, hopes, and delusions, the viewer is swept up in the storm of his creative fruition, bordering on the insanity and emotional fragility that makes up the core of Inarritu's film. When we first see Riggan, he is literally floating in mid-air in his dressing room, a ludicrous first shot that boldly establishes the subjective unreality of the film, and immediately establishes a clear directorial vision, one that will be impossible to outwit or predict, making for a deeply compelling and intimately truthful performance based piece of storytelling. According to the demands of the one shot take that establishes the subjectivity of the narrative, every other actor's performance becomes a part of one long stream of Riggan's conscious and subconscious, each line delivered with the grace and elocution of live theatre, the players all a part of one organism in motion, their individually delivered performances in active participation with the creation of Keaton's persona, the entire film brimming with a communal vitality. In establishing a film centered on, around, and within one character, Inarritu has created his own subjective world in Birdman, one that mirrors the celebrity driven popular culture of our own, each one of us supporting actors and walk-on's in the theatre of celebrity and fame, all of us culpable in the ignorance of Riggan Thomas.

In this way, Inarritu's film is about solipsism, with its closest precursor in terms of thematic scope and directorial vision being Charlie Kaufman's 2008 directorial debut Synecdoche, New York, wherein the subjective reality of the New York actor and playwright is examined with the fierceness of an unforgiving and distinctively authorial force, at times remarkable in its overstated ambition and pretentious precocity. And yet, Birdman is never overly heady, as Kaufman's film is, never treading too far into the subjective lens so as to become impenetrable, self-avowedly brilliant but visually opaque. Where Kaufman seems to be too overly in love with his own brilliance, his protagonist suitably left in a literal apocalypse of his own creation by film's end, Inarritu's Riggan is relatively warm, capable of emoting and connecting with those around him, even if they are all forced to co-inhabit his own subjective dreams and nightmares. Where Kaufman's New York Theatre is filled with shadows of narrative misdirection and evasion, coupled with the indecipherable, Joycean mutterings of the literary intelligentsia, Inarritu's is inhabited with the light of the artist still struggling to connect with his audience, embittered towards the academic establishments of theatre and film criticism, and eager to engage with Carver's comparatively accessible text. Birdman is a worthy successor to Kaufman's film, more immediate and emotionally compelling than Synecdoche's grand opera, delivering the equivalent of a three and a half minute pop song to Kaufman's twenty-two minute progressive rock noodling, Synecdoche, Lite in essence.

Despite the near insurmountable ambition and hubris of the film's concept and subject matter, Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's Birdman lives up to the self-conscious precocity of its subtitle, examining the socio-cultural status of the Hollywood celebrity through the eyes of a falling star. Michael Keaton makes a stunning comeback performance as Riggan Thomas that ranks as one of the best performances of the year, in addition to an already enviable body of work from the past. The level of meta-fictional, self-reference that Keaton is able to pull upon to lend some empathetic tragedy and intimacy to the iconographic nature of a former Hollywood superhero is effectively comical and heartbreaking, Riggan's professional and personal association with the Birdman character as inseparable from his sense of self-identity as Batman is to Keaton in the public eye, lending the film much of its satirical bite and cultural relevance. And yet, for all of its carefully composed strategic plotting that might feel a little too smart for its own good in anyone else's hands, Inarritu never falls prey to cinematic convenience or contrivance, his story of artistic redemption moving and dramatically satisfying, hopeful despite the melancholy of its character's solipsistic ambition. When Riggan finally soars free at the end of the film, both in terms of creative fulfillment and surrealistically projected fantasy, the final note is hopeful, even though the viewer knows that the character still resides within his own head, ignorance his and our creative bliss, made necessary once more by the film's titular and unexpected virtue.

The Oscar nominees were announced yesterday, and there are some surprises. I like how Whiplash, my favorite film of 2014, was nominated for Best Picture, and it's good to see Dick Poop get the attention he deserves as a cinematographer (yes, I'm actually going to start with a joke about that flub). One movie that didn't surprise anybody was Birdman, which was nominated for many awards. I have seen this movie today, so now I am going to review it.

The film centers around Michael Keaton's character, who played the lead role in a superhero movie franchise twenty years ago, and now is a washed up actor who hasn't been in much lately (sound familiar). In an attempt to kickstart his career again, he writes, and stars in a Broadway play. The movie is about his struggles with his lack of confidence, as he tries to make this play.

This movie is advertised as a dark comedy, but it doesn't really have as many humorous scenes as you may think. It is also artsier than the average dark comedy, with most of the movie being done in one long take, and with frequent sequences that seem to be in his imagination.

The film's casting is clever. In addition to casting Michael Keaton in a role that could almost be considered autobiographical, there are also actors who were in other superhero movies, such as Edward Norton (The Incredible Hulk) and Emma Stone (The Amazing Spider-man).

The film itself is a pretty good one. It has an interesting story, and is very well directed. It's different from most movies, and I like that. It is not so much a comedy as a satire of the entertainment industry with occasional bursts of humor. It discusses the struggle of has-been actors, as well as how actors are treated according to others' expectations for them.

Birdman is an intriguing, unique movie, that is sure to win a few awards.

A satirical and clever look at the Theatre and its distain for Hollywood, a humorous look at Hollywood and its love of celebrity, whilst also reflecting on social media and the world of viral success. All of that, expertly moulded into one film that is part All About Eve, part Batman and part Noises Off and part Sunset Boulevard. It's also a strong look at mental illness and the pressures of success in the modern world. 
Michael Keaton is amazing. Almost forgotten in Hollywood, Keaton's most recent outing was the very forgettable Robocop remake, for which he was a very underwhelming villain. Here, he clearly knows the material is top notch. 
But the supporting cast is also excellent, with not a single poor performance or weak link. Edward Norton (playing a satirical version of himself) is brilliant as he switches from amazing stage actor, to egotistical and destructive before suddenly becoming rational and logical. 
Zach Galifanakis is a revelation in his role, so much more subdued and layered than his usual comedic buffoon. And Emma stone continues her climb in Hollywood with another great performance.
The film, not seeming a big budget film, takes place mostly in one location, inside a theatre. This gives the film feeling of being a stage play (much like old Hollywood films that were based on plays such as The Petrified Forest or Wait Until Dark) that the limited sets give away the story's theatre roots. However, the film suddenly explodes into a Hollywood comic book movie, with very impressive visual effects. Birdman 4 looks like it would be a great film to go and see.

Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's Birdman made a large buzz on the Film Festival circuit before (finally) securing a wider release. Getting a lot of word of mouth, not only for the quality film making and interesting continuous sequence look, but also because of star Michael Keaton. Keaton, probably still best known for his turn as Batman in Tim Burton's 1989 landmark film does a fantastic job playing an aging actor, past his prime and out of his depth in Birdman.

Riggan (Michael Keaton), a once prominent action star is trying his hand at being the lead actor in a play he wrote the adaptation of and is also directing. The play is a project to show the world, and more importantly himself, that Riggan isn't a relic of the past who can only act in a rubber suit. To paraphrase Riggan's daughter, Sam (Emma Stone), that he matters. Riggan's agent and best friend, Jake (Zach Galifianakis), is stressed with trying to balance actor's egos, an ever changing cast, and other stresses that go along with opening a major Broadway production. Mike (Edward Norton) a true performer, lover of the stage, and arrogant actor is brought in last minute to replace a cast member that dropped out. Mike's love of the craft could make or break Riggan's play. Lesley (Naomi Watts) and Laura (Andrea Riseborough) round out the rest of both the play's cast and the movie's cast.

Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu may not be a household name for many casual movie goers but a quick search on IMDB will undoubtedly ring a few bells for any movie fan. He directed movies like 21 Grams and Bable, just to give you an idea. Trying something that isn't often attempted, Inarritu shot all of Birdman in what appears to be one long sequence, a single take. This technique was most famously done by Alfred Hitchcock in the fantastic movie Rope. More impressively in Hitchcock's time was the limitation of a reel of film, being only so long forced Hitchcock to make cuts and hide them to keep up the look of a single take. Inarritu had technology on his side and used a few techniques, like time lapses, to keep the continuous sequence. In addition to the continuous sequence, the shots and framing are outstanding. The camera feels alive. The angles are creative and follow the action like audiences bobbing their heads back and forth at Wimbledon. The only time the camera is at rest is when the days are transitioning during very well executed time lapses.

Michael Keaton is famous for playing an iconic super hero thirty years prior, he is also an aging actor. The similarities to Riggan stop there. Keaton is a steadily working actor who had a career before he donned a rubber suit and worked steadily his whole life after. Keaton is a fantastic actor who does Drama as well as he does comedy and can now add crazy to his resume. Riggan's is clearly unhinged. Talking to his alter-ego of Birdman throughout most of the film it is clear. Edward Norton is pure Broadway, New York City, 'starving' artist. Starving isn't literal since it is established that his character, Mike, is successful and wide regarded, but Norton plays the stereotype perfectly. Arrogant yet insecure off stage, when it is time for Mike to act he is unmatched. Riggan deals with the craziness of the actor to escalate his play. Emma Stone, Naomi Watts, and Andrea Riseborough are also all amazing performers. There really isn't a weak actor in the entire movie, but a special mention should be made for Zach Galifianakis. Galifianakis is most famously known for his role in the very successful Hangover franchise. Playing an awkward idiotic man-child Galifianakis is incredibly funny. In Birdman he sheds the comedy (and more than a few pounds) to become a full fledged actor. While not an actor within the movie Galifianakis does a fantastic job playing the straight man alongside so much insanity.

Sadly, Birdman is guilty of going a bit too far on some things and stepping over a few thin lines that separate brilliant from absurd. The film has Riggan imagining himself with psychic powers, the ability to fly, and being truly more than a simple man. These instances are completely unneccesary. It is clear that Riggan is teetering on the edge because of Keaton's amazing performance. The inner voice was all that was needed to drive the message home. The added science fiction of it all makes it seem like the director didn't have enough faith in his actor to get the job done. There is one larger than life sequence that is supposed to be the turning point for Riggan. The entire scene amounts to nothing, and even makes Riggan's next big move seem out of character. This scene seems to have been shot entirely for the benefit of the trailers. There is also some imbalances in the characters. So much time is spent with Mike and his own version of mental illness that when the character disappears from the movie it feels like a loose end that will never be tied up. Mike isn't dismissed in the form of an open ending or ambiguous results, he is dropped outright.

With only a few faults to speak of, Birdman is an incredibly directed, acted, and written drama. The continuous sequence look is a technical achievement as well as a totally engrossing way to keep audiences latched to the screen. We are so trained to look for breaks when one doesn't come we practically forget to blink. Michael Keaton is mesmerizing, Edward Norton is commanding.

Keaton plays Riggan Thompson, a former Hollywood actor, best known for playing the role of a superhero known as Birdman in three blockbuster movies. His career suffering since he turned down a forth film. Thompson seeks to recapture his fame by making it as a theater actor.  Throughout the film he has to deal with his co-star, his rebellious daughter, and Birdman himself, who symbolizes his self-doubt. Only real criticisms being I felt the critic played by Lindsey Duncan was a little too strong. Though I agree everyone has their personal tastes when it comes to acting, to wanna kill a play simply because the lead actor is known for playing a superhero seems rather unprofessional. Also the I felt the scenes between Stone and Norton seemed unnecessary. But overall, these are minor criticisms.
 Admittedly  the theme of the film is a bit difficult for me. One possible theme is life imitates art shown in such scenes when Keaton's character seems to gain super powers. Though it seems to be more of a symbol of his character going mad. Another theme is just wanting to be loved. This is supported by the fact the films lead wishes to regain his former popularity, and repair his relationship with his daughter. Hence the play What We Talk About When We Talk About Love.
 Birdman draws you in with it's visual style. As the film is shot, for the most part, to look like it's all one take. This was done to give the film the feel of watching a theater play. It's a very unique style that draws people in and immerses them  in the films story. 
 In conclusion, Birdman is a very odd, but unique film, with a deep story, and fantastic performances. The only real disappointment I can think of, is for people expecting a superhero film about Birdman.

Birdman's use of (an apparent) single shot does much for the movies tone and feeling, for better or for worse. It makes the film feel raw and real for the audience as you watch the events unfolding and with such naturalistic feeling that the film ebbs and flows thanks to the crisp cinematography and direction and the stellar screenplay. However, because the film never cuts, the film is constantly ebbing and flowing which after a while becomes strenuous physically and mentally as the film's ability to hold attention needs to be maintained. Fortunately it does, for the most part.

But because of the stellar achievement of film just from the technicality of the filming process and the eventual product on screen, its masterful to look at. The film boasts a fine cast who are all 100% invested in their work and character that the film feels so 'real'. Birdman's only flaw is the sometimes drawn out pacing that may lead to a tired person occasionally nodding off to sleep.

"Birdman" is a character study in more ways than one. But under Alejandro Iñárritu's ("Amores Perros", "21 Grams") capable hands, it is also an experimental film that many other directors have tried before in one form or another. It is made to look like it was filmed in one long unbroken shot from beginning to end with continuous scenes. It is technically impressive with its ensemble acting, writing and cinematography as the standouts. It is also the type of film that may polarize audiences. Those who have seen other experimentally influenced films from Stanley Kubrick, Lars von Trier or Pedro Almodovar know what I'm talking about. But while Iñárritu's approach to the material he also co-wrote is very unconventional, it is far from being inaccessible.

Set against the backdrop of actors trying to launch a new Broadway play, the film deals with so many themes including, but not limited to, the ephemeral nature of success, the question of relevance, confusing love for admiration, the quest for what is truly art vs. pop culture and the longing for instant gratification where the definition of achievement is measured in terms of having countless "likes" or "followers" instead of a lifetime or body of work - universal themes for all of us.

Scenes around New York City and its theater world play secondary characters here. The film was shot near Times Square at the St. James Theater where I saw "The Producers" with Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick.

"Birdman" is multi-layered, open ended and allows for more than just one interpretation. It is simply brilliant.

A virtual masterpiece, Birdman is a shoo-in for the Oscars but still manages to be a edge of the seat, highly watchable film. Arthouse is often a dry bleak affair, all interpersonal drama and poignant character study with no meat and often no soul. This goes triple for November oscar-bait movies. But Birdman, if you would pardon a bad pun, is a bird of a different feather. It hits on all levels. Director Inarritu creating a modern day fable about a washed out hollywood actor trying to reinvent himself with a Broadway adaptation of Raymond Carver. MIchael Keaton's character, Riggan used to be big, then he became 'too big' when he played superhero birdman in three blockbusters. Many years later he is washed out, a shadow of his former self and is desperately trying to prove to himself and others that he is a true actor once more. When he comes face to face with new co-star Mike, a 'true' Broadway method actor Riggan's life, play and sanity slowly start unravelling.

Let's start with the cinematography. Inarritu is a great director but the real merit in Birdman's spectacular, unbelievable pacing and its construction as a 'single shot' movie (yes, the whole movie is one -two maybe?- 'faked' tracking shot.) go to cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki, who was also responsible for Tree of Life and almost all of Cuaron's movies: Gravity (a movie I hated but whose technical merits stand firm), Y tu Mama Tambien (a movie i loved), Children of Men (remember _that_ tracking shot?) and many many more. Even if we disregard the faux one-shot style this movie looks stunning, with the framing, the often dream-like lighting and some incredibly framed transitions standing as testament to just how important a good DP is to a movie.

The score is stunning, a collage of freeform drumbeats that manage to 'break the fourth wall' in regards to whether or not they are diegetic or not and keep the pacing up, driving the story along at times. It is simply unbelivable how simple but at the same time powerful Birdman's score can be. God bless Antonio Sanchez and fuck the Academy for its bullshit rules.

Finally, the acting is simply fantastic with not one single performance dragging the movie down. Michael Keaton puts a nuanced and at the same time batshit crazy performance in and is contrasted extremely well with the incredibly natural Ed Norton. Emma Stone, of Amazing Spiderman infamy plays seamlessly off those two, a telling example of how a good acting environment can push others to greatness. Speaking of which - Zach Galafinakis. God damn, he might not be the greatest actor out there but he really does give his best in this one. Also Billed: Naomi Watts who i've never liked but puts on a good if slightly exagerrated performance and Andrea Riseborough who i only know from the dreadfully forgettable Oblivion but who I'm sure i'll be seeing more of.

Birdman is a modern classic and an unforgettable film. It is certainly a movie i'll be watching again, a meaty, juicy film about theatre, stardom, depression and oblivion that everybody should see.

Upsetting. Deeply unsettling. Pretty damn brilliant and worrisome. Had to wait a few minutes before leaving the theater to figure out exactly what I was feeling and settle my heart and stomach into their proper places.

What is a Birdman? An actor in a costume who became a cultural icon two decades ago in the fictional timeline of Hollywood movies in the fictional version of the world not so different from ours-- in fact exactly similar, except that Michael Keaton, Emma Stone, Naomi Watts, Edward Norton and Zach Galifianakis are different people, trying to make their voices heard in the extremely complicated and competitive realm of Broadway theatre. We are shown the film as if its a single shot being played out for 2 hours, through the help of some excellent editing techniques, as we follow the lives of these characters on stage and mostly backstage where they battle it out against each other and with themselves as they search for their soul.

Birdman was one of the most ambitious films of the year and Alejandro Gonzales Inarritu managed to pull off this very unique film about a former movie star trying to get back in the spotlight through a broadway film. At first that is what it seems it is going to focus on but it does touch on more deeper meanings involving his family and his relationships with himself and those around him. Michael Keaton was definitely the best part of the film, he portrayed Riggan so well that i began to believe that this could have actually been a real person. He showed so much passion in playing this character that you really get sucked in to his amazing performance. The supporting cast i felt also did a pretty good job but did not shine as brightly as Keaton. Another highlight from the film has to be the ingenious and mesmerising method used to film it. The one-shot sweeping camera technique used gave this film a very different feel than many other films and really let you follow these characters and get to see them in all different environments without all of the jarring cuts. The performances as well as shooting technique are what make this film what it is. But that was still not enough for me to absolutely love this movie, the overall tone of the film didn't really work for me, i understood why they went for a dark and comedic yet also dramatic tone as there were some sections that i really enjoyed but for the most part i couldn't really enjoy the entire film as much as i wanted to. Despite not being able to really enjoy this film as much as i had hoped, i still got to see one of the performances of the year in one of the more different films of 2014, if you are an admirer of some different, quality film this may be the film for you - 7.6

Birdman is the best movie about an untreated delusional schizophrenic since American Psycho. Like the latter, you see the world through the protagonist's prospective. The story isn't necessarily based entirely based on reality and it's up to the viewer to interpret what's really happening. Though there are obvious delusions, one has to wonder if even every day activities are happening or its just in their head. To take it to an extreme, one could wonder if he really was a movie star. Was he really a Broadway actor? Nothing is a given. This unpredictability makes the movie stand out from cookie cutter movie story lines. 

Micheal Keaton, the first real movie Batman, sorry Adam West, is the perfect actor to portray a man typecast in one particular role. No matter what Keaton does, the majority of the population over 30, who were alive to see his movies, will still see him as Batman. 

But now the younger generation of millenials have a different reference. They think of Batman as Christian Bale and soon maybe Ben Afflec, depending on how good he is. If he's like George Clooney or Roger Moore as Bond, he may just be a fleeting impersonator. The New Coke of a Hollywood Icon.

When teens like this movie and decide to go back and watch Batman or Batman Returns they'll say, "Birdman was a pretty good Batman."

Critics don't mind weird, obviously; they've seen that before. But have they really? Birdman is unusual, eerie, even painful to the ear sometimes. Maybe that's the point. Beautifully designed as a seamless, fluid sequence means no respite for the audience in an intense study of celebrity and hubris. The most unique quasi-independent film since Being John Malkovich, but devoid of the self-importance and elitism that plagues the works of Kaufman and Jones.

Michael Keaton leads the charge as a teetering schizophrenic actor, struggling to find validation on Broadway after a long, expired run as a glossy Hollywood blockbuster-dweller. On a purely technical level, it's astounding. Precisely edited to appear as though the whole thing were executed in one extremely long take, it's a mesmerizing experience, profoundly different and expertly crafty when the timeline needs to leap forward. It's dazzlingly acted, too, with Keaton delivering a masterful performance alongside noteworthy supporting work from Ed Norton, Emma Stone and (to my surprise) a very versatile Zach Galifianakis. The moral lessons are laid on thick, though, and too often it feels like we're being lectured for daring to indulge in the kind of loathsome fun that drove our lead to this strange brand of mania. One scene in particular, Keaton's confrontation with a stuffy critic before opening night (who glares right into the camera before storming off in a cloud of self-righteousness) plays like a direct scolding of the audience. Maybe theatre purists will take this as a firm voice of reason, the rare call of someone who finally *gets* it, but to me it came off as tremendously stuck-up and pretentious. I can't deny there's a lot to enjoy here, and it's a clear arrival for auteur Alejandro González Iñárritu, but I also can't help wondering how much better it would be without that permeating air of superiority.

Birdman: or Woody Allen meets Faust. Okay, it's slick and cutting edge; the dialogue is razor sharp most of the time and the acting is high class. There is wit and at times we laugh out loud. And the way it is shot means we are often backstage and part of the ensemble that is struggling to launch the show on Broadway. 
The trouble for me is, even allowing for the fact that actors can be wrapped up in their own melodramas to a greater extent than those they are employed to portray, this sad and sorry collection of individuals eventually brought me down to their level - one of unmitigated gloom and despondency. The result was, feeling they were architects of their own fates, I ran out of patience with their stupidity and no longer cared what happened to them.
Excellent though he is in the lead, as the one-time superhero attempting to resurrect a career otherwise heading towards the toilet pan, Keaton's character (who can only speak the lines given to him) seems to suffer from a death wish that would thwart even the archangel Gabriel. In fact the whole cast in this play within a play (with the possible exception of Emma Stone as Keaton's daughter - who almost steals the whole show in my view) seem so consumed by their own misery they tend to forget they are on the verge of launching a play that has the potential to actually succeed.  But success does not seem to be what this is all about. Even when handed the golden key to Broadway, Keaton prefers to sabotage the project by veering off on a tangent of his own making. I was with them for a good three-quarters of the journey, but felt by the end they were best left alone to drown in their respective sorrows.
I can see why so many viewers of this film are on their feet and applauding, but for me, proficient though it undoubtedly is,it contains an element of the king without his clothes on. Consequently I found its particular version of nudity somewhat tiresome. It might be cleverer than I am giving it credit for, but, you know what? I don't always want to feel as if I am sitting an exam when I go to the movies!

Marvellously mad. Surreal swirls with the human melodrama and personal torment of Michael Keaton as his all or bust debut low fi Broadway play launches. You think there is a story behind the stories but in the end there isn't really.

Absolutely spectacular. A 2 and a half hour spectacle of the inner workings of the mind of Riggan (Keaton) and his battle with himself complete with an unforgettable drum motif and suspense tactics that will make you stir. Stellar performances from Norton and Stone; I'll be shocked if Norton doesn't nab that Oscar. A tenacity is brought by the both of them and collided so sweetly. The directing is simply something I have never seen before. I am in awe of the "long take" appearance and how that mirrors the theatrical premiss of the film. Michael Keaton delivers an incredible performance. His portrayal of his washed up character is believable and simply one for the books. Go see this with people who appreciate the analytical side of films and editing and not your average movie goers. Birdman is just a fantastic film from start to finish. From the incredibly detailed direction from Inarritu to the pitch perfect acting from the entire ensemble (Keaton gives an award worthy performance). Birdman was the film in 2014 I have been waiting for. Alejandro Inarritu has constructed a feast for the eyes as the majority of Birdman's two hour run time is shot and edited in such a careful way that the film looks like one long scene. My eyes were glued to the screen as I marveled at the technical wizardry i was witnessing. Add the score by Antonio Sanchez which is mainly a drum set playing elaborate solos and fills creating an unpredictability in the film. The screenplay is top notch as this drama/comedy likes to pick fun at how blockbusters have taken over Hollywood and the struggle for a small/independent project to get made. The dialogue scenes between characters are by far the best constructed I've seen all year. The ensemble as i said earlier is perfect. Everyone brought their A-game. Even Zack Galifianakis surprised me playing a reserved role instead of a loud, fumbling idiot. But it truly is Michael Keaton who is the brightest of the star. The inner battle with Riggan propels the movie from one character to the next. Keaton's performance is definitely worth an Oscar Nomination (and he will probably win). This is on the Academy's radar for best picture of the year and it should be because in my eyes it is the best film I have seen all year! If you have a chance to check out Birdman I suggest you take it. It will be a film you will not forget anytime soon.

Full of in-jokes, cliches and self indulgence, Birdman is as pretentiously heavy handed as its jazz-drum soundtrack. Few critics have dared to be honest and nail this movie to the wall as the smugly self-important wank-fest that it is. There is an Emperor's New Clothes hype surrounding this film that I can't fathom. Maybe critics are too afraid of being labelled a vitriolic curmudgeon like Lindsay Duncan's character in the movie; a long since defunct pastiche of theatre critics. She is just one of the many clichés and stereotypes which litter this movie: the overpaid, narcissistic actor/director-on-the-edge; the over-burdened, neurotic manager; the brattish, rebellious daughter; the insecure, needy actresses and of course, the genius-but-impossible-to-work-with, method actor. 
Even the clever in-jokes are over-played, like the casting of two actors embittered by their stints as superheroes to satirically act out their real-life reputations, Keaton famous for playing on-the-edge characters (Beetlejuice, Batman and Dream Team), Norton famous for being notoriously difficult to work with. I found it hard to stomach these actors, both of whom made super-rich by their trade, ironically riffing on the amount earned by RDJ for Iron Man, even as art imitating life, imitating art. We get it! Don't labour the point to absurdity. Hollywood is solely about the money and imaginatively bankrupt. We get it! 
I am being a bit unfair, the casting and acting does redeem this film, as does the amazing cinematography, but as demonstrated by other actor-indulgent-films, like American Hustle last year, allowing actors to improvise does not necessarily make for realistic, gritty dialogue. It comes across as stilted, unfocused and self indulgent, just like this movie. It won one well deserved Oscar for Best Cinematography. Best Director, okay I can appreciate Alejandro González Iñárritu's vision and his talent at getting such performances from such notoriously difficult actors. Best Film? I don't think so, though not really surprising when looking at the narcissism of the voters, "Ooh look, a film all about me". That said, I am deeply appalled that such a hackneyed story, full of clichéd characters spouting unrealistic dialogue, could win Best Original Screenplay when compared to the other nominees. A travesty.
more different than I thought but a weird good surprise.

Once in awhile those few gems will come around and remind you of why you watch films in the first place, while I still think Boyhood is the best of 2014, Birdman joins a pretty awesome list of those films of 2014. Birdman is a truly excellent film that does so many unique things and actually has something to say. 

I'd like to think that in my reviews that I come across as someone that doesn't just try to say snarky comments just to have something to quote on a DVD case. I love film and review films from a personal and passionate standpoint, not just to look at the technicals and tear into people. However, it feels like a joke to even try review Birdman because one of its many themes that it addresses is critics, which has an excellent scene and that rant where Riggan just tears into that critic is a fantastic scene and hopefully one that got a few people thinking. Michael Keaton really felt like he pulled from his own life experiences for this film but especially for that scene in particular and I wonder how much of it was ad-libbed. 

The pseudo-biopic angle that this film has going is quite surreal, I wonder if when the actors read the script they just thought of something strange or a remark to say to the filmmakers. All of the characters in this film seem to be played up to be exaggerated versions of the actors, Keaton more than most, obviously; and strangely enough it works really well, even if some aren't used that much near the end, unfortunately. Keaton said that Riggan is unlike himself and that works even more in the films favor for the exaggeration and they have the same amount of letters! He also said it was the most challenging film he has ever done but that hard work really paid off! I'd hate to use the term 'washed up' because, especially in Keaton's case, I don't believe it because he's been consistently working for many years now and I just don't like that term anyway. 

The acting in this film is outstanding and everybody does an excellent job, the script is brilliant and they all work fantastically with each other, through excellent dialogue and well developed relationships. The way the script references things that have happened in 'the real world' does give it that extra touch of realism. This film seems to have shielded itself from criticism in a way, clearly not because it doesn't have 100%, but if anyone has a complaint about it, people, or at least people I know, would have a little laugh and a joke about them bringing up a complaint. However, there was one scene, just one, where the acting felt really fake. One character was yelling at another character about something and whilst their body language and face were acting out that moment, their eyes didn't seem like they were in the moment and it just felt really manufactured, it reminded me I was watching a film. I know that's a real nitpick if there ever was one but hey.

Seeing as how I haven't really spoken about structure yet and just used big words to label everything, why don't we talk about the story? The way everything is put together in this film is some of the best filmmaking I've ever seen, it looks like one shot but it isn't and there are points when it looks like you can tell where it's been cut but having everything look like one long take certainly gives the film a new kind of life. While I haven't seen a film that was actually one take, like Russian Ark, at the time of writing this, this style really puts you into the story. I felt totally engrossed in this film and I felt like I was there with them, this totally gives new meaning to the term, 'experience', it's smartly assembled and the transitions are flawless. At first, when I saw a few little clips of the film, everything looked to be close ups of the characters and I'm glad the whole film wasn't filmed like that because that would have gotten annoying really quickly. I love why the director chose to have it all be one take, because life is all one take and doesn't have cuts, that's awesome. The soundtrack is much like the film, it is unpredictable and feels improvised, especially in scenes involving the unique, stylised text, to fit the moment that it's playing with, which is brilliant.

Besides everything else that already makes it unique, a lot of what happens in the story are things that I don't think I have ever seen before. It's just so refreshing to watch something that really has something to say about pretty much everything, this film tackles so many interesting subjects from interesting angles from its excellently written characters and it really gives the audience a lot to think about, not just critics. It's an emotional film and it is totally unforgettable. But hey, it should have been Birdman 2 where Riggan stooped, not 3 but that's pretty clever why it was 3 and 1992 was the right year, odd that, isn't it...

Birdman, and it's very Dr. Strangelove-like name, or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance) is a perfect film and something that was made for the right reasons that really has something to say and it was all filmed in under a month, terrific. With brilliant effort from everyone involved, Birdman is, just simply, a masterpiece and one of the best films I've ever seen.

En este filme que uno de sus factores es la carga de haber encarnado a un super-héroe hace muchos años, no es raro encontrar liderando al elenco al brillante Michael Keaton quien dio vida a Batman en el fenómeno cultural mundial que fue el filme de 1989 y repitiendo el rol en 1992. Pero es también curioso encontrar a Edward Norton, quien fue el Dr. Bruce Banner en "The Incredible Hulk", segundo filme del Phase 1 del Universo Cinemático de Marvel, y para rematar tenemos a Emma Stone, quien encarnó a Gwen Stacy en las primeras dos entregas de la actual saga de "The Amazing Spider-Man". Pero no se equivoquen, quien vaya al cine a ver este filme porque busca ver otro filme más de super-héroes que ahora es algo regular, se darán una gran sorpresa ya que fuera de mencionar de una forma muy casual que el personaje principal (Keaton) encarnó a un héroe en el cine llamado "Birdman" (sin ninguna relación salvo el nombre con el personaje de Hanna-Barbera, aunque bien puede ser una amalgama de ese Birdman y Blue Falcon), hasta ahí llega el vínculo con el glamoroso universo de los héroes uniformados. Incluso me extraña que los Globos de Oro la hayan metido en la categoría de comedia, ya que salvo un momento irremediablemente divertido, la película es eminentemente un drama. Una de los principales detalles de esta cinta es haber sido filmada "en una sola toma" o la ilusión de haber sido así ya que fue realmente un impecable trabajo de edición para que parezca así, aunque no es algo nunca antes visto, ya que el filme de horror "La Casa Muda" hecha en Uruguay en el 2010, usó esta misma idea, solo que manteniendo además el factor de tiempo real, o sea los eventos duran lo que dura la cinta, lo cual no es así aquí en "Birdman" donde el gran trabajo de edición y fotografía crea una ilusión efectiva donde la trama tiene evidentes saltos temporales pero no así en la "toma" que se vé en pantalla. En cuanto a la atmósfera de la cinta, podría considerarla como una mezcla entre "Black Swan" y el esquema típico de un filme de Woody Allen, que tal vez por esa similitud a una cinta de Allen es que la consideraron una comedia, pero honestamente no creo que eso sea acertado. El director, Alejandro González Iñárritu (Amores Perros, Babel, 21 Grams, Biutiful) maneja un impresionante elenco de actores sacándoles actuaciones muy buenas, pero creo que lo criticable sería el guión, el cual es un script que permite sacar a luz aspectos internos de las personalidades de los actores, principalmente Edward Norton, ya que si bien Michael Keaton hizo a "Batman", dudo mucho que en la realidad se sienta con ese personaje, como lo hace en el filme con respecto a "Birdman" (de hecho el ha comentado que este personaje es el más diferente a como es él en la vida real que ha actuado), pero creo que el guión pudo ser más crudo, más personal, más revelador, y además la trama no tiene un norte claro ni un propósito evidente salvo visitar a esta gama de personajes en su interacción durante unos cuantos días de sus vidas cuando una obra de teatro está por estrenarse. El factor surreal de la historia es brillante pero igualmente, al carecer de un objetivo claro la historia en general, como un todo, salvo obviamente el deseo de la mayoría de la gente de dejar una huella en este mundo, de ser recordados, pero sobre todo de ser recordados por lo que nosotros queremos y no por lo que la gente decida, sin embargo, creo que el filme queda debiendo un poco en establecer una coherencia estructural completa en su guión, que es brillante sí, pero difícil de asimilar como un todo. Pero eso no significa que no sea algo interesante de observar y dónde su final (tranquilos no voy a hacer spoilers) es simplemente genial e inapreciable, algo breve pero monumental y abierto a ser debatido por años.

You don't really have to watch it; it pulls you up by the roots. You want to stay with it, because it's too good to leave behind. You're running along with this film chasing it's characters and eventually stepping into their shoes. The Director blurs the line on how close you can get as an audience member. Celebrating performance and also berating uninspired social hierarchy, the media, critics, people on the interwebs.  For me, Birdman gets to the painstaking truth lying just beyond ideas we have about being famous, or successful. It takes you seriously into America's fantasizing, and explores deeply the circles of entertainment. You almost expect to have an intermission, because it requires so much focus, but the film takes respite from its constant motion. Like a well-crafted painting, it leaves moments for the audience to "rest" upon before coming at you with another detailed edge. Mostly I just wanted to applaud the performers, their production team, and the director. EVERYONE involved really, that's because it's such a gem- designed by what must be an incredible team of inspired individuals. Birdman is the play, within the movie, within real life that we all must desperately want to be a part of. Keen audience members will remark that the space in which all things happen is really the star of the show. Life it seems is CAPTURED with a flash and a picture frame. Performance is drawn, lifelike, out of the "real" situations to only to rise and then fall back into the space of the moving picture. Like man known to death, Birdman knows it's own convictions and place in existence. It's aware that it's a "Movie" and seems to want to crash down those walls securely hanging it there. Mostly just incredible through and through, it's a must watch for the season, and for the year. Delivering the kind of mind-bending experience needed the kids these days all tuned in, and never letting you breathe until it's over. So go, and witness all the magic and depth that modern story telling can provide. Draft Two (to be edited and revised)

Dark, funny, weird and original Bird man did in 30 days what it takes some directors a year. A movie shot to look like a play, about an actor who might be magic on the brink of irrelevance putting on a play, Bird Man is a refreshing movie experience for those who are tired of the typical hollywood blockbusters we've become accustomed to from lazy directors like Michael Bay, or James Cameron. Michael Keaton shows us once again why it's a crime he has never been nominated for an Oscar, and why his first nomination could be his first win. Edward Norton once again shows us his prowess and versatility as an actor playing an actor with serious problems that lead him to clash with Keaton and make us think he could also have his first win here, with possibly his strongest performance of a long and brilliant career. Galifianakis, and stone both exceed expectations with career high performances. Put all this together and what you get is the disturbing, funny, and brilliant movie that bird man is, and if it's success in the award season doesn't convince you than watch it yourself and you'll wonder how you ever doubted this movies potential. If you have any beefs with my review feel free to message me.

Birdman is an exceptionally well made film.  It is beautiful, smoothly done, rough on the senses, disorienting and touching.  I need to see it again just to wrap my head around it and have been thinking about it continuously since I viewed it.  

The direction and cinematography is superb.  The casting and acting are spot on and create a synergy that glues the film together.

You've got to give Inarritu a lot of credit for not taking the conventional route whatsoever with what could have potentially been a cliched-ridden premise and end result.  Thanks to the meticulous direction, the semblance of seamless continuity helps guide the film along, sweeping in and out throughout the film's two hours.   

There are lots of diatribes coming at a rapid-fire pace from several characters, most rather thought-provoking in context, even if the actual language used comes off as more academic/philosophical or suited for (dare I say it given the movie's subject matter) a play setting.   The supporting cast (even Emma Stone and Ed Norton) is either thinly drawn in depth or barely shown on screen, likely on purpose to keep the focus squarely on Michael Keaton and allow him to shine.
Original, interesting and strange - I loved it. Keaton and Norton are superb.
The acting was phenomenal by the entire cast. Keaton was by far the best of them all. Should win best actor for his role. The movie was funny and entertaining.

After reading all the great reviews, I was really looking forward to seeing Birdman  but I was sorely disappointed. The story doesn't develop into anything particularly interesting and I didn't care what happened to any of the vacuous characters. As far as I can see, the reason for the rave reviews must be down to the unique filming technique with all the long takes which is different to anything I've seen before, (even though there is more than one occasion where somebody fluffs their lines but it was left in the final cut), and the acting which, to be fair, is very good. All in all, Birdman left me feeling empty. It's self-indulgent, pretentious nonsense that doesn't deserve the 5 star reviews it's been getting. Not by a long shot.

"Birdman" is a black comedy about a mentally unstable theater actor (Michael Keaton) who struggles with both internal and external demons in a constant battle to become his true self. The social "mask" that he has put on is one of a successful play director and actor, but beneath the façade he has created, he longs for spiritual liberation and to become his true and authentic self. He used to play the superhero Birdman on Broadway, and he felt more at ease and himself when in that role. The whole movie is a metaphor for his cathartic struggle to break free of a life he is miserable in, and the voice in his head that torments him is his id trying to break free. This movie is brilliantly acted, superbly directed, and tautly scripted. It is poetic in parts and tragically funny in others. Michael Keaton, Emma Stone, Edward Norton and the entire supporting cast all display fine acting, which makes the movie both an easy contender for Best Picture and will undoubtedly find some of the actors with nominations as well. The message is the movie is existential, and is embedded within many layers of profound metaphysics and the issue of authenticity that so many existentialists have struggled to solve. The film is intelligent and creative in its approach and is one of the most complex films of 2014. Immensely enjoyable if not tragic -------------------------------------------------------- A

If Michael Keaton wasn't the lead, I think this film would not have done as well. Not because of his acting, mind you (he did a splendid job), but rather his background. He was Batman - excuse me - "Birdman" - and the audience knows it and makes that connection. Without that not-so-subtle real world connection, what lure would this story have?

While it is certainly well made and the actors do a good job with what they are given, it left me wondering what I just watched. There is little, if anything, that is really new regarding subject matter. The sets are realistically grungy and New-York filthy. As a technical production, it goes back to the few-cuts approach used by the likes of Hitchcock, and does it well. But why?

Ultimately, I see this as an example of film that will be studied by art directors and editors. It is a movie for people who make movies, and they will be the people who love it the most. For me, it's an oddball that never really drives its message home, though it shows off a lot of talent in the attempt.

It is one of those artsy fartsy movie with excellent technical showcase (can we get  Iñárritu an Oscar please?), all around amazing acting and brilliant script about showbiz satire. 'Birdman' is an interesting film, but also a movie about a Broadway play - not the most invigorating subject. The concept of a former Comic Book Movie Star trying to re-start his acting career on Broadway is certainly unique, and the film has a great look - especially the way it's filmed to look almost as if it's one continuous shot. There's a few laughs, but this is definitely not a comedy.

Keaton (Riggan) is great and ably supported by Stone (Sam, his daughter), Norton (Mike - happy to get around in underpants or his birthday suit for most of his scenes) & Watts (Lesley, his co-stars), although Galifianakis is a little wasted. Even though the cinematography is good, the fact it's basically one shot means there's a fair bit of wasted time as we follow characters down hallways. Probably could've been an efficient 100min film, rather than two hours. The other thing I found annoying was the drum/cymbal fills - they're in his mind, but are very distracting.

It's essentially about ego and the driving force behind actors. Sure, Riggan is a more delusional character than most actors (hopefully!), driven by his insecurity. As the critic says to him: "you're not an actor - you're a celebrity". Burn. The ending is, like the whole film, different, but not completely satisfying.
Unless you like an art type of movie do not go and see this I was bored the whole way through wondering when it was going to end. The trailer makes it seem a lot better than it actually is.
Possibly one of the coolest movies I've seen. From the all drum soundtrack, to the fact that it's basically an entire continuous shot, this movie is basically perfect.

Great direction, script, and acting troupe make this film a great watch. Michael Keaton plays a washed up action hero who sinks all the cash he has left in his ageing and dwindling existence into staging a Broadway play, hoping it will make him relevant again. This film is shot to look like it flows in one clean shot, the camera flows alongside the actors, capturing everyone's foibles, their struggles with existing in a world where everyone needs to be seen as something great, where if they can't make it in this life they will slink back into the shadows and crumble into sand. Edward Norton and Michael Keaton are quite superb here as the two male leads, the female characters are not written as strongly but Watts does well with what she has as does Stone as the ex addict daughter who just needs to be loved by her father. It's a great film and Keaton deserves the Oscar talk. Good to see Galifianakis with a serious role, can show he has the acting chops instead of mugging it for laughs.
Birdman excelleert in elke vorm van filmmaken, met fenomenale prestaties van zijn acteurs tot de kleinste detail in muzikale vorm. Dit toont hoe je kunst kan maken uit een film !

Probably one of the most original and inventive movies of the 20th century (I'm sorry, it's now 21st century), because of not only the long continuous shot of it, but on how a character is transformed into something we wouldn't dare expect and so the other characters as well. Anyways, Birdman is one of the best American movies ever, also one of the best Stage play dramas ever to put on film since Synecdoche, New York last 2007 or 2008 which some critics claimed it to be the best of the 2000s. Inarritu's direction is one that should definitely get an Oscar nomination, look at how he (Inarritu) shot face to face and set to set and area to area, it's truly one of a kind. The performances, I keep saying this over and over again, but here it's no excuse, Keaton should deserve his long awaited best Actor nomination and so does Norton too who I think his best Best movie performance to date since 1998's American History X. Emma Stone and all the other female supporting characters here should get some praised for some of their important and meaningful roles that as we see it, not portrayed as some street hookers or f****d up women. Did I also forgot Zach Galifaniakis here? Is also his fine role here than what we used to see him in some stupid comedic roles, thoroughly a breakthrough performance. The more that I think and go deeper on how Birdman was shot and filmed, I thought of how you can create a piece of art without copying or plagiarizing other people's work, so you see it here, Inarritu's direction is a work or art, from as I said it earlier, the score, the introduction of Keaton and the other characters, the stage with and without the audiences, the stress on and off the stage, the father and daughter arguments, Keaton and Norton arguments, Keaton and his women, the people outside the theater, the New York in day and night, and to the last scene which I can say is more of a resolution to the Birdman. I also found out on the news that they are making a sequel to Birdman and it's gonna be about believe it or not, the prequel to King Kong. 
Other than that, great stuff, we wish we're gonna see more films like this.
Disturbing and confusing but compelling to watch to the end.
